	<script type="text/javascript">
		/* <![CDATA[ */
		function addLoadEvent(func) {
			var oldonload = window.onload;
			if (typeof window.onload != 'function') {
				window.onload = func;
			} else {
				window.onload = function () {
					oldonload();
					func();
				}
			}
		}
		/* ]]> */
	</script>

		</div>	</div>

	<div class="masonry-subheader__life-nav">
		<ul>

	</div>

</nav></header>

Days","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"See Thurgood Marshall&#8217;s Career Before His Supreme Court Days","excerpt":"He became the first African-American Supreme Court justice on Aug. 30, 1967","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"Aug. 30, 2017","published":"2017-08-30 11:00:07","updated":"2017-08-30 15:00:07","minute":"11:00 am","short":"8\/30"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module ad-300-250\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4913195\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4913195\/thurgood-marshall-supreme-court-photos\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>When Thurgood Marshall was <a href=\"https:\/\/www.archives.gov\/historical-docs\/todays-doc\/?dod-date=830\" target=\"_blank\">confirmed<\/a> to the Supreme Court 50 years ago &mdash; on Aug. 30, 1967 &mdash; the United States&#8217; highest court gained its first African-American justice. The confirmation was a crowning achievement in Marshall&#8217;s already long and illustrious legal career, which was well documented by LIFE Magazine in the years leading up to that day. As shown by these LIFE photos of his career in the years between 1949 and 1967, he was &mdash; as the magazine once dubbed him &mdash; the &#8220;chief counsel for equality.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Working on behalf of the NAACP, he had tackled <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=-1YEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA40&amp;dq=%22thurgood+marshall%22&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiH1Oe2p_DVAhUG5yYKHckWCX04ChDoAQgnMAA#v=onepage&amp;q=%22thurgood%20marshall%22&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">segregation<\/a> in courts across the South and Washington, D.C., and even his most dedicated opponents could not help but admit to his skill. Though his friends had thought him foolish for taking on civil-rights cases early in his career &mdash; especially because he often did that work unpaid &mdash; he had turned his passion for those cases into history-defining success.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;[The] leading civil rights lawyer of his time is a surprising man, full of contradictions,&#8221; LIFE <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=bVYEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA141&amp;dq=%22thurgood+marshall%22&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiH1Oe2p_DVAhUG5yYKHckWCX04ChDoAQgvMAI#v=onepage&amp;q=%22thurgood%20marshall%22&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">noted<\/a> in a 1955 profile. &#8220;No solemn crusader, he is high-spirited, loud-talking and wisecracking. Profoundly devoted to a cause, he usually looks and sounds like a man who is mainly concerned with satisfying his zest for life.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Despite all his success thus far, his colleagues noted at the time that he always got nervous before he had to argue something before the Supreme Court, though he pepped up as soon as he got going. And yet that profile, written <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=GlMEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA14&amp;dq=%22thurgood+marshall%22&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiH1Oe2p_DVAhUG5yYKHckWCX04ChDoAQg3MAQ#v=onepage&amp;q=%22thurgood%20marshall%22&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">at the height of<\/a> the fight over segregation, ended on a prophetic note: &#8220;As Thurgood Marshall left the Supreme Court building last week,&#8221; LIFE noted, he squared his shoulders and said, &#8216;We&#8217;re gonna be back.'&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From An honors graduate of Columbia Journalism School and Hamilton College, she grew up in New York City.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"OBWax","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/OBWax","gplus":"107906059620632524688","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_1445.jpg?quality=85&crop=81px%2C115px%2C2671px%2C2671px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Olivia+B.+Waxman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/olivia-b-waxman\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4873326\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4873326\/princess-diana-childhood-photos\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Before Diana was the Princess of Wales, she was Diana Spencer. And while contemporary audiences may <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4879138\/diana-princess-remembered\/\">remember<\/a> Diana &mdash; who died 20 years ago this Thursday, at 36, in a car crash in Paris &mdash; for braving the <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4881423\/princess-diana-celebrity\/\">paparazzi<\/a>, in her early life she was known for being the shy and quiet one in her family.<\/p>\n<p>The above photos shed light on her early life, from scenes at her birthplace, Park House, to family summer vacations in Sussex. As TIME described her privileged upbringing in <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/vault\/issue\/1981-04-20\/page\/1\/\">an April 20, 1981, cover package<\/a> published shortly after the then-19-year-old Diana became engaged to the Prince of Wales Charles, the house that the Spencer family rented from the Crown had the only heated pool in the area &mdash; and that pool was more than a symbol of wealth. Because Park House was part of the royal estate at Sandringham, the neighbors who came by to take advantage of the pool included the Windsor children. &#8220;Diana and Charles may have met a few times when she was a child and he already a young man, but everyone is fuzzy on the details,&#8221; the story noted.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>That pool was not the only indicator of her privilege, the story continued:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>Diana attended West Heath, a boarding school in Kent, where she excelled in sports and recorded a middling result on standard exams known as O Levels. At 16, she spent twelve weeks at a Swiss finishing school, primarily to learn to ski but also to brush up on French, cooking, sewing and typing. Nothing much here for a r&eacute;sum&eacute;, but perfectly fine, thanks, for the sort of genteel, pass-the-time employment that came Diana&#8217;s way: governess, cook, nanny, kindergarten teacher.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/pages.email.time.com\/newsletters\/?newsletter_name=HISTORY&amp;source=article-history\"><em>Get your history fix in one place: sign up for the weekly TIME History newsletter<\/em><\/a><\/p>\n<p>But, despite having all the makings of a happy childhood, that period could also be a solitary one for the young Diana. She had a strong connection with animals, doting on her Shetland pony and serving as head of &#8220;Pets&#8217; Corners&#8221; at her boarding school Riddlesworth Hall, but often spent time without many people around. Her parents&#8217; marriage having fallen apart before she was 10, the family home Althorp House could be &#8220;a lonely place&#8221; for Diana, Tina Brown, the former editor of <em>The<\/em><em> New Yorker<\/em> and <em>The <\/em><em>Daily Beast, <\/em>writes in the forward of the new book <em>Remembering Diana: A Life in Photographs. <\/em><\/p>\n<p>&#8220;A frequent erroneous press assumption,&#8221; she writes, &#8220;was that her distinguished aristocratic background meant familiarity with a grand, high-society world. In fact, Diana&#8217;s childhood was limited in its circle and almost feral in its neglect. She spent most of her free time with the servants below stairs (one reason, perhaps, she could communicate so well with ordinary people).&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"History","slug":"history","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/history\/","description":"The news in context, from the archives of TIME. 13:30:02","minute":"8:00 am","short":"8\/19"},"authors":[{"id":291298709,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/eliza-berman\/","name":"Eliza Berman","bio":"","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lizabeaner","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lizabeaner","gplus":"","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2015\/07\/eliza-berman-time.jpg?quality=85&crop=110px%2C74px%2C801px%2C800px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":false,"author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/eliza-berman\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module ad-300-250\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-3737424\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3737424\/solar-eclipse\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>If you are one of the<a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4906819\/solar-eclipse-map-watch\/\"> lucky Americans<\/a> in position to see <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4750899\/total-solar-eclipse\/\">Monday&#8217;s total solar eclipse <\/a>&mdash;which will <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4884482\/total-solar-eclipse-2017-map\/\">touch 14 states<\/a> as it crosses the country from coast to coast &mdash; you&rsquo;d do well to take a tip from 1963&rsquo;s fifth grade class of the Emerson School in Maywood, Illinois. Wielding cardboard boxes and knives that today would surely get a kid suspended, the kids demonstrated for LIFE&rsquo;s readers how to safely look at an eclipse.<\/p>\n<p>During the solar eclipse of 1960, hundreds of people had suffered permanent eye damage from looking directly at the sun. With help from the Illinois Society for the Prevention of Blindness, Emerson students avoided the same fate by building Sunscopes, pinhole camera-like contraptions that indirectly project an image of the sun. The magazine offered instructions for those desiring to replicate the project at home:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>To build your own, get a carton and cut a hole in one side, big enough to poke your head through. Paste white paper on the inside surface that you will be facing. Then punch a pinhole into the opposite side, high enough so that the little shaft of light will miss your head. For a sharper image you can make a better pinhole by cutting a one inch square hole in the carton, taping a piece of aluminum foil over this hole and then making the pinhole in the foil. Finally, tape the box shut and cover all light leaks with black tape.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>A final word to the wise from LIFE: &ldquo;Don&rsquo;t forget to come out for fresh air.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<p><em>Liz Ronk, who edited this gallery, is the Photo Editor for LIFE.com. Follow her on Twitter at <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">@LizabethRonk<\/a><\/em><em>.<\/em><\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Waxman","bio":"Olivia is a Staff Writer. An honors graduate of Columbia Journalism School and Hamilton College, she grew up in New York City.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"OBWax","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/OBWax","gplus":"107906059620632524688","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_1445.jpg?quality=85&crop=81px%2C115px%2C2671px%2C2671px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Olivia+B.+Waxman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/olivia-b-waxman\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module ad-300-250\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4866576\"><\/div><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>The above gallery features some familiar feline-friendly faces: There&#8217;s a 1959 photo of writer Ernest Hemingway, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.hemingwayhome.com\/cats\/\" target=\"_blank\">who collected six-toed cats<\/a>, with a cat helping itself to a glass of water. (Hemingway&#8217;s cats may have drunk more than water, with one<a href=\"http:\/\/www.smithsonianmag.com\/smart-news\/ernest-hemingway-taught-one-of-his-many-many-cats-to-drink-whisky-73691\/\" target=\"_blank\"> letter<\/a> suggesting the author fed one named &#8220;Friendless&#8221; whisky and milk when he was feeling lonely and wanted to drink with somebody.) And there&#8217;s Fred Astaire palling around in 1962 with the Siamese cat that fellow film star Kim Novak, also pictured, had given him. &#8220;Animals loved Daddy,&#8221; his daughter Ava later told <em>Vanity Fair<\/em>&#8216;s editor-at-large, Sarah Giles.<\/p>\n<p>But it&#8217;s also clear that a cat can be a star whether or not its owner is famous. For example, in 1958, when Navy doctor Dietrich Beischer used magnet boots to train a kitten to chase a mouse upside-down, to get a sense of how humans would deal with weightlessness, the cat played an important role in the history of space travel. And as for a cat in a funny hat or a cat eating corn on the cob &mdash; well, some things never change. After all, <a href=\"http:\/\/entertainment.time.com\/2013\/04\/18\/internet-cats-behind-the-memes\/\">every day is cat day<\/a> in the age of social media.<\/p>\n<p>For the International Fund for Animal Welfare&#8217;s International Cat Day this Tuesday &mdash; a purrfect excuse for such a gallery &mdash; here&#8217;s a look at 25 of the best feline photos in LIFE&#8217;s iconic archive of Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4861239\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4861239\/vintage-photos-american-cowboy\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>A big reason why some enthusiasts will <a href=\"http:\/\/nationaldayofthecowboy.com\/wordpress\/\" target=\"_blank\">celebrate<\/a> &#8220;National Day of the Cowboy&#8221; on Saturday is the idea that &#8220;cowboy culture&#8221; needs preserving.<\/p>\n<p>And it turns out that&#8217;s not a new feeling. Nearly seven decades ago, that same idea &mdash; that a particular Western lifestyle would not survive much longer on its own &mdash; was already looming.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/life-cowboy-cover.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=376\" data-attachment-id=\"4861534\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4861239\/vintage-photos-american-cowboy\/1269522-jpg\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/life-cowboy-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1793,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;LEONARD MCCOMBE&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;LIFE cover 08-22-1949 w. cowboy C. H. Long.&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;-642556800&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;1269522.jpg&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"LIFE magazine Cowboy Cover\" data-image-description=\"pAug. 22, 1949 cover of LIFE magazine featuring cowboy C. H. Long.\" height=\"376\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4861534\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4861239\/vintage-photos-american-cowboy\/1269522-jpg\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/life-cowboy-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1793,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"LEONARD MCCOMBE\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"LIFE cover 08-22-1949 w. cowboy C. H. Long.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/life-cowboy-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=224\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/life-cowboy-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=447\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/life-cowboy-cover.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=376\" alt=\"Aug. 22, 1949 cover of LIFE magazine featuring cowboy C. H. Long.\" height=\"376\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Leonard McCombe&mdash;LIFE Magazine<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >Aug. 22, 1949 cover of LIFE magazine featuring cowboy C. H. Long.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>When LIFE profiled a cowboy for the <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=00kEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PP1&amp;pg=PA62#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">Aug. 22, 1949, issue<\/a>, with photographs by Leonard McCombe, the land on which the cowboy once slept was already dotted with new ranch houses, and office jobs were looking more and more attractive as the post-war economy boomed. &#8220;Like the frontiersman and the forty-niner, the traditional cowboy is a peculiarly American type, now following them into an honorable extinction,&#8221; the story noted. &#8220;He is being replaced by feebler men, who refuse to work grueling hours, to go wifeless and broke to the end of their days.&#8221;<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>In fact, the story was billed as a &#8220;last look&#8221; at the &#8220;oldtime cowboy.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The man at the center of that tale was Clarence Hailey &#8220;C.H.&#8221; Long, a 20-year Texan veteran of the profession who found freedom in a life of solitude and physical hardship. He personally trained all 13 of the horses he used to do his job, and his home on the range looked &#8220;exactly as a moviegover would expect.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>But in that fact, LIFE acknowledged, lay one of the more subtle truths about the past and future of the cowboy lifestyle.<\/p>\n<p>Even as C.H. Long was a living embodiment of a beloved, but endangered culture, he was already part of a myth forged by Hollywood and dime-store novels, not reality. He knew that the cowboy image that the the world celebrated was sometimes more appealing than even the most rewarding liberties of life on the cattle trail.<\/p>\n<p>And on his rare trips into town, he picked up magazines full of Western stories, which he dismissed as &#8220;claptrap&#8221;, but loved nonetheless, &#8220;forgetting his adventurous life to search for adventure in lurid accounts of wild affairs that never happened.&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Archives","life":true,"all_sections":["time-section-history","time-section-life"]},"tag":{"name":"photography","slug":"photography","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/tag\/photography\/"},"tags":"1949|Cowboy|Leonard McCombe|onetime|photography","hero":{"class":"landscape","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/iconic-cowboy-02.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","src":{"small":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/iconic-cowboy-02.jpg?quality=85&w=280","small_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/iconic-cowboy-02.jpg?quality=85&w=560","landscape_large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/iconic-cowboy-02.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/iconic-cowboy-02.jpg?quality=85&w=550","large_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/iconic-cowboy-02.jpg?quality=85&w=1100","square":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/iconic-cowboy-02.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1"},"credit":"Leonard McCombe\u2014The LIFE Images Collection\/Getty Images","caption":"<b>Caption from LIFE.<\/b> At sunset after a day's work, he collects his string of horses, considers which of the young ones to pick for a training session.","title":"Clarence H. Naktong With Thousands of Korean Refugees","excerpt":"In 1950, LIFE documented the plight of refugees during the Korean War","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"June 20, 2017","published":"2017-06-20 09:00:12","updated":"2017-06-20 13:00:12","minute":"9:00 am","short":"6\/20"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4817950\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4817950\/north-korea-world-refugee-day\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>In the early weeks of the Korean War, which had <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3915803\/korean-war-1950-history\/\">begun in June of 1950<\/a>, LIFE Magazine dispatched a bevy of journalists to <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=wUoEAAAAMBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;dq=%22refugees+get+in+way%22&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwim8_TNqL7UAhWMMSYKHYR_DlsQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&amp;q=%22refugees%20get%20in%20way%22&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">cover the conflict from all angles<\/a> for the Aug. 21, 1950, issue of the magazine. One of them was Carl Mydans, a <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4326758\/photographer-spotlight-carl-mydans\/\">long-time LIFE photographer<\/a> who was also a dependable correspondent.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=390\" data-attachment-id=\"4818845\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4817950\/north-korea-world-refugee-day\/korean-refugees-life-magazine\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2405,1674\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"Korean Refugees LIFE magazine\" data-image-description=\"p\u201cRefugees Get In Way\u201d\u00e2&#128;&#148;from the April 21, 1950 issue of LIFE magazine.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=600\" alt=\"&quot;Refugees Get In Way&quot;&acirc;&#128;&#148;from the April 21, 1950 issue of LIFE magazine.\" height=\"390\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4818845\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4817950\/north-korea-world-refugee-day\/korean-refugees-life-magazine\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2405,1674\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"Korean Refugees LIFE magazine\" data-image-description=\"p\u201cRefugees Get In Way\u201d\u00e2&#128;&#148;from the April 21, 1950 issue of LIFE magazine.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/korean-refugees-life-magazine.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=390\" alt='\"Refugees Get In Way\"&acirc;&#128;&#148;from the April 21, 1950 issue of LIFE magazine.' height=\"390\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Carl Mydans&mdash;LIFE Magazine<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >&#8220;Refugees Get In Way&#8221;&mdash;from the April 21, 1950 issue of LIFE magazine.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>For his slice of the war, Mydans reported on witnessing a potentially tragic situation in which thousands of refugees were trapped between the two military forces. In his notes on the project, which were sent back to LIFE&#8217;s offices and have been preserved in the magazine&#8217;s archives, Mydans wrote that refugees were &#8220;a major problem&#8221; for the war effort. As they fled from the North to the South, filtering through the U.S. forces going the other way, their groups were infiltrated by North Korean fighters dressed as peasants, who would fire on the Americans from the rear as soon as they got past. Newly arriving units from Japan and the U.S. thus &#8220;vowed they would tolerate no such civilian movement&#8221; but quickly found that such a promise was a difficult one, as the civilians were not enemies and refusing to allow them to flee a war zone was not feasible, neither in a moral nor a practical sense.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>On Aug. 6, 1950, that problem was thrown into stark relief right in front of Mydans&#8217; eyes: Though the U.S. forces had made an effort to clear out all of the villages near their lines, to prevent the need for civilian movement, the American 1st Cavalry Division found itself face to face, across the shallow Naktong River, with more than 5,000 refugees hoping to cross. Behind the refugees were North Korean fighters. If a battle began between them and the Americans, the refugees were right in the middle.<\/p>\n<p>It was decided, Mydans noted, &#8220;with an understanding of the terrible conditions these war victims were in, with no homes, no food, and the almost sure danger that they would find themselves between two fires, when the river battle finally opened up,&#8221; that South Korean and American forces would screen them as they crossed.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;What happened in the crossing, how they carried their young and old on their backs and heads,&#8221; Mydans wrote, was shown better in the photos than he could describe in words. &#8220;This is a picture story &mdash; the kind that make the few correspondents with me hope they could present this story in pictures rather than with the typewriter.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>And yet, when a few of Mydans&#8217; photos ran in the magazine, the editors chose a selection of his words to accompany them, too &mdash; and in those words is a message that&#8217;s particularly relevant on <a href=\"http:\/\/www.un.org\/en\/events\/refugeeday\/\" target=\"_blank\">World Refugee Day<\/a>, which falls this year on Tuesday. The details may have been specific to Korea, he observed, but the plight of the refugee and the need to extend a helping hand was a universal one.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4817950\/north-korea-world-refugee-day\/mydans-captions-korea-detail\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/mydans-captions-korea-detail.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2405,455\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/mydans-captions-korea-detail.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2405,455\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" of Surfing in 1963","excerpt":"Celebrate the sport with a peek into LIFE Magazine's archives","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"June 16, 2017","published":"2017-06-16 08:30:27","updated":"2017-06-16 12:30:27","minute":"8:30 am","short":"6\/16"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lilyrothman","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lilyrothman","gplus":"115083326003510988963","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_2552.jpg?quality=85&crop=364px%2C105px%2C2338px%2C2337px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Lily+Rothman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/lily-rothman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module ad-300-250\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4800287\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4800287\/hawaii-surfing-1960s-photos\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>If there was one message LIFE magazine had for readers in May of 1963, as <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3879962\/international-surfing-day-classic-photos-of-surfers-from-hawaii-to-peru\/\">the surf craze<\/a> swept the U.S. and <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4361986\/international-surfing-day-2016-gidget\/\">popular images of surfers<\/a> tempted newcomers into the water in the <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4804171\/jack-oneill-dead-surfing-wetsuit-pioneer\/\">days before wetsuits were common<\/a>, it was that surfing was fun <span class=\"s1\">&mdash; <\/span>but it wasn&#8217;t all fun and games. It was also dangerous, especially when it came to the waves found off the North Shore of Oahu.<\/p>\n<p>The magazine kindly <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=mEkEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PA1&amp;pg=PA56#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">explained<\/a> to unfamiliar readers how the sport worked there: &#8220;The men who ride the big ones in Hawaii actually ski down the shoulder of a wave away from the curl&#8230; They call the first breathtaking schuss &#8216;taking the drop.&#8217; Their boards accelerate up to 35 mph so rapidly that they kick up waves like speedboats. And a merciless mauling awaits the unfortunate who doesn&#8217;t complete his ride. He is driven downward by the appalling maelstrom, tossed around, sucked back down and frequently, after fighting up for a desperate gulp of air, hammered down again by the next wave.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>And yet a brave group of surfers &mdash; fewer than 100 people at that point, three of whom had been killed in 1962 &mdash; sought out the big waves anyway, for what LIFE called the &#8220;peril and ecstasy&#8221; of the sport&#8217;s toughest waves. Enabled by new innovations in balsa wood surfboards that had opened new vistas to surfers in the 1940s, they returned again and again, despite the risks.<\/p>\n<p>Looking at these color photos by George Silk, it&#8217;s not hard to see what drew the surfers back to the water. In honor of <a href=\"http:\/\/www.surfrider.org\/isd\" target=\"_blank\">International Surfing Day<\/a> on June 17, here&#8217;s a look back at what surfer Fred Van Dyke described to Silk as &#8220;the greatest feeling the world.&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's &#8216;Having It All&#8217; Played Out 70 Years Ago","friendly_title":"How the Conversation About Women \u2018Having It All\u2019 Played Out 70 Years Ago","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"How the Conversation About Women &#8216;Having It All&#8217; Played Out 70 Years Ago","excerpt":"On Women's Equality Day, a look at what's changed \u2014 and what's stayed the same","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"Aug. 25, 2017","published":"2017-08-25 09:00:42","updated":"2017-08-25 13:00:42","minute":"9:00 am","short":"8\/25"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lilyrothman","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lilyrothman","gplus":"115083326003510988963","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_2552.jpg?quality=85&crop=364px%2C105px%2C2338px%2C2337px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Lily+Rothman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/lily-rothman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4901910\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4901910\/american-womans-dilemma-womens-equality\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Ever since the very first <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4459168\/womens-equality-day-bella-abzug\/\">Women&#8217;s Equality Day<\/a> was celebrated in the United States, the annual Aug. 26 event has marked more than just the anniversary of the 19th Amendment&#8217;s extension of voting rights. It has also commemorated the struggle for a <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4010645\/womens-equality-day\/\">deeper<\/a> kind of equality in all realms of life.<\/p>\n<p>But, though much progress has been made toward that goal, some things have barely changed in decades. Case in point: LIFE magazine devoted a lengthy <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=mEgEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PA1&amp;pg=PA100#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">1947 story<\/a> to the &#8220;American woman&#8217;s dilemma,&#8221; and the details of that dilemma are problems still faced today. The sub-headline just about summed it up: &#8220;She wants a husband and she wants children. Should she go on working? Full time? Part time? Will housework bore her? What will she do when her children are grown?&#8221; These questions ring familiar to present-day debates about whether, and how, women can &#8220;<a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3453839\/kirsten-gillibrand-have-it-all\/\">have it all<\/a>.&#8221;<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>In 1947, with the post-war United States awash in considerations of how women ought best to spend their lives, LIFE profiled how a selection of American women had answered that question. A generation before, the story noted, the women in the story would likely have been happy &mdash; or at least put on happy faces &mdash; about seeing marriage as a &#8220;complete future.&#8221; But when the story was published, they could be businesswomen, lawyers, factory workers, gardeners, harpists, television announcers, secretaries or housewives, like the woman featured in the photos above &mdash; who, the story noted, did that work a whopping 100 hours a week, even with the help of modern appliances.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-medium alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?w=300&#038;quality=85&#038;h=288\" data-attachment-id=\"4901991\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4901910\/american-womans-dilemma-womens-equality\/housewife\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1553,1490\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" Marjorie McWeeney broom amidst symbolic display of her store beds to be items glass pieces silverware food some data-image-title=\"1947 Woman\u2019s Dilemma\" data-image-description=\"pHousewife Marjorie McWeeney w. broom amidst symbolic display of her week\u2019s housework at Bloomingdale\u2019s store incl. 35 beds to be made, 750 items of glass &amp; china, 400 pieces of silverware to wash, 174 lbs. of food to prepare, some of 250 pieces of laundry\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=600\" alt=\"The American woman&#039;s dilemma in 1947 from LIFE magazine.\" height=\"288\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4901991\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4901910\/american-womans-dilemma-womens-equality\/housewife\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1553,1490\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"NINA LEEN\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"Housewife Marjorie McWeeney w. broom amidst symbolic display of her week's housework at Bloomingdale's store incl. 35 beds to be made, 750 items of glass & china, 400 pieces of silverware to wash, 174 lbs. of food to prepare, some of 250 pieces of laundry\",\"created_timestamp\":\"-712800000\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"HOUSEWIFE\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}\" data-image-title=\"1947 Woman\u2019s Dilemma\" data-image-description=\"pHousewife Marjorie McWeeney w. broom amidst symbolic display of her week\u2019s housework at Bloomingdale\u2019s store incl. 35 beds to be made, 750 items of glass &amp; china, 400 pieces of silverware to wash, 174 lbs. of food to prepare, some of 250 pieces of laundry\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/08\/womans-dilema-chores.jpg?w=300&#038;quality=85&#038;h=288\" alt=\"The American woman's dilemma in 1947 from LIFE magazine.\" height=\"288\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:300px\"><span class=\"credit\" >Nina Leen&mdash;The LIFE Picture Collection\/Getty Images<\/span><span class=\"caption\" ><b> <\/b>A week&#8217;s work for Marjorie McWeeney is assembled by Bloomingdale&#8217;s store. <\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>Many more professional avenues are available to American women today than were in the past, but the basics of this 70-year-old story will still ring true for many. The full-time workers, at least those who could afford to have a choice in the matter, had to earn enough to cover childcare costs. Those who stayed home full-time were faced with an uncertain future if they planned to return to the workforce later, though by LIFE&#8217;s count U.S. housewives at that time contributed unpaid labor worth $34 billion ($378 billion today) to the economy each year.<\/p>\n<p>If they did not plan to return to work after their children were grown, they faced a life, in the magazine&#8217;s words, of being &#8220;bored stiff.&#8221; Part-time work was a partial solution, but it was hard to find and hardly feasible for those who actually needed the money they earned.<\/p>\n<div id=\"action_button_container\"><\/div>\n<p>And, as Frances Levison <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=mEgEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PA1&amp;pg=PA100#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">wrote<\/a> in an essay to accompany the story, all this analysis of the &#8220;dilemma&#8221; had an &#8220;inevitably disturbing effect&#8221; on the gender in question &mdash; serving as a reminder of one more kind of inequality faced by American women: the inequality of attention to what she was doing. &#8220;Probably no man has ever troubled to imagine,&#8221; the essay quoted the writer Dorothy Sayers observing, &#8220;how strange his life would appear to himself if it were unrelentingly assessed in terms of his maleness.&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Archives","life":true,"all_sections":["time-section-history","time-section-life","time-section-living"]},"tag":{"name":"Family","slug":"family","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/tag\/family\/"},"tags":"1947|Family|feminism|gender|LIFE Magazine|Nina Equality Day: Dilemma of the American Woman","description":"Seven decades ago, LIFE magazine presented this analysis of the state of American women's lives. Some things haven't changed since then.","google_news":"women's equality day, womens equality, american women, jobs for women, vintage photos american women, part-time job for women, american Ago","og_desc":"For Women's Equality Day, a look at what's changed \u2014 and what's stayed the same","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4879138\/diana-princess-remembered\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2h9WMMk","title":"The World-Changing Evolution of Princess Diana","friendly_title":"The World-Changing Evolution of Princess Diana","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"The World-Changing Evolution of Princess Diana","excerpt":"Read an excerpt from the newly reissued LIFE special edition 'Diana: A Princess Remembered'","format":"gallery","modified_time":{"pretty":"Aug. 9, 2017 5:07 PM","published":"2017-08-09 17:07:15","updated":"2017-08-09 21:07:15","minute":"10:00 am","short":"8\/9"},"authors":[{"id":373061337,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/life-books-2\/","name":"LIFE Books","bio":"","short_bio":"","types":[],"twitter":"","twitter_url":"","gplus":"","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":null,"contributor":false,"search_link":false,"author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/life-books\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4879138\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4879138\/diana-princess-remembered\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p><em>The following is an excerpt from the newly reissued LIFE special edition<\/em> Diana: A Princess Remembered,<em> available in the <a href=\"http:\/\/ti.me\/2tGcK2l\" target=\"_blank\">TIME Shop <\/a>and<a href=\"http:\/\/amzn.to\/2gO9XSP\" target=\"_blank\"> on Amazon.<\/a><\/em><\/p>\n<p>The flowers were remarkable. In the hours and days after the death of the Princess of Wales, mourners from all over the United Kingdom streamed to the gates of Buckingham Palace, to St. James&rsquo;s Palace, to Kensington Palace to lay bouquets in tribute to the woman known just as Diana. There were so many flowers &mdash; more than one million &mdash; that in descriptions, only metaphors from nature seemed to suffice: a sea of flowers, waves of them, a mountain. There were also poems, letters and teddy bears, and once the shock of Diana&rsquo;s death subsided, it took three days for London to remove the symbols of heartbreak. Prime Minister Tony Blair, in a now famous speech in the rain outside of his church, remembered the 36-year old princess for the nation.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>&ldquo;People everywhere, not just here in Britain, kept faith with Princess Diana. They liked her, they loved her, they regarded her as one of the people. She was the People&rsquo;s Princess and that is how she will stay, how she will remain in our hearts and our memories for ever.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<p>It has been 20 years since Diana&rsquo;s death but never has the legacy of this remarkable woman been more relevant for the House of Windsor. A family long defined by its chilly reserve is now praised for its candor (at least sometimes) and willingness to break with tradition (ditto). This year, Prince William and Prince Harry have begun to speak movingly about their emotional struggles in the wake of their mother&rsquo;s death. William took as his wife a commoner, Kate Middleton, the woman he loves, unlike his father, Prince Charles, who was compelled to marry out of duty to the crown. Diana&rsquo;s grandchildren, Prince George and Princess Charlotte, are being raised as part of the wider world, not sequestered from it. Even Queen Elizabeth, whose relationship with her daughter-in-law was famously strained, has shown signs of Diana&rsquo;s influence, in visits to AIDS clinics, a cause she reportedly discouraged Diana from supporting.<\/p>\n<div class=\"page\" title=\"Page 1\">\n<div class=\"layoutArea\">\n<div class=\"column\">\n<p>Na&iuml;ve, beautiful and sheltered, Diana could not have been a more unlikely agent of change for the British monarchy, the one to drag Buckingham Palace from the Victorian era into the 20th and 21st centuries. She was born in a home on one of Queen Elizabeth&rsquo;s country estates and raised in an ancient tradition that didn&rsquo;t ask scholarship of its females but instead put a premium on them being proper and respectable &mdash; attractive catches for aristocratic young men. As she grew up, Lady Diana Spencer met expectations, and on paper, was the perfect match for Charles, the heir to the British throne. Their fairytale nuptials on July 29, 1981, were dubbed, as the pages ahead reveal, &ldquo;The Wedding of the Century,&rdquo; and they enchanted the world. But we know now the marriage was doomed before it was started and that 20-year-old Diana was ill-equipped for a husband who did not love her. She foundered and struggled and withdrew &mdash; but then emerged &ldquo;The Mouse That Roared,&rdquo; as <em>Vanity Fair<\/em> memorably put it, discovering a reserve of strength as well as a common touch that the ruling family lacked.<\/p>\n<p>Diana learned to control the narrative and outshone her husband at every turn. She became both the fashionista with drop-dead backless dresses and the Good Mum running barefoot in the parents&rsquo; races during field days at her boys&rsquo; school. She could comfort a child whose leg had been lost to a land mine and hug an AIDS patient in an era when many, including the Windsors, feared such a gesture. Diana showed an intrinsic talent for connection, and she won the people&rsquo;s love even as she evolved into a global superstar. The Windsors however misread the whole story. If they had only perceived in Diana&rsquo;s public persona their new, best asset, rather than viewing her as a threat or an affront, they might have shared in the glow of her fame and charisma. Instead, they missed the point and missed their opportunity. Diana became the heroine, one who left an indelible imprint and won credit for modernizing an out-of-touch family.<\/p>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<\/div>\n<figure class=\"inline-inline_small alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4879138\/diana-princess-remembered\/princess-diana-life-book-cover\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1769,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1769,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"Princess Diana LIFE Books\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=221\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=441\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-cover.jpg?w=190&#038;quality=85&#038;h=258\" alt=\"LIFE books, Diana a Princess Remembered.\" height=\"258\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Terence Donovan&mdash;Trunk Archive<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>The shift was evident in the years after her death, but was crystalized for the public during the 2011 wedding of William and Catherine Middleton. Following the reception at Buckingham Palace, the prince whisked his bride away in a dark blue convertible from Aston Martin, makers of James Bond&rsquo;s favorite coupe. Thirty years earlier, Diana and Charles had been driven from the palace in an open-topped State Landau with footmen, like a scene out of Cinderella. Diana had always dreamed of being a princess. She had, as a girl, believed in fairy tales. But then as a woman, she rewrote the stories for her sons.<\/p>\n<p><em>Read more in the newly reissued LIFE special edition<\/em> Diana: A Princess Remembered,<em> available in the <a href=\"http:\/\/ti.me\/2tGcK2l\" target=\"_blank\">TIME Shop <\/a>and<a href=\"http:\/\/amzn.to\/2gO9XSP\" target=\"_blank\"> on Amazon.<\/a><\/em><\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Pregnancy.","width":1603,"height":2405,"orientation":"square","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4879138\/diana-princess-remembered\/photo\/ut-981997\/","encoded_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4879138\/diana-princess-remembered\/photo\/ut-981997\/","twitter_via":"","encoded_title":"The+World-Changing+Evolution+of+Princess+Diana","encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Fti.me%2F2vnTWXe","twitter_encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Fti.me%2F2vnTZ5m","email_title":"The%20World-Changing%20Evolution%20of%20Princess%20Diana","twitter_text":"The%20World-Changing%20Evolution%20of%20Princess%20Diana","fb_text":"The%20World-Changing%20Evolution%20of%20Princess%20Diana","email_body":"The%20World-Changing%20Evolution%20of%20Princess%20Diana%0A%0ARead%20an%20excerpt%20from%20the%20newly%20reissued%20LIFE%20special%20edition%20%27Diana%3A%20A%20Princess%20Remembered%27%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4879138%2Fdiana-princess-remembered%2Fphoto%2Fut-981997%2F","src":{"small":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=180","small_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=360","landscape_large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=180","large_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=373","square":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1","fullscreen_fhd":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=720","fullscreen_qhd":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/princess-diana-life-book-05.jpg?quality=85&w=960"}},{"id":4879163,"title":"Princess 'Diana: A Princess Remembered'","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4592406\/john-g-morris-100\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2heq3oq","title":"Celebrating Legendary LIFE Photo Editor John G. Morris","friendly_title":"Celebrating Legendary LIFE Photo Editor John G. Morris","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"Celebrating Legendary LIFE Photo Editor John G. Morris","excerpt":"His friends and colleagues reflect on his century of influence on photography","format":"article","time":{"pretty":"July 28, 2017","published":"2017-07-28 17:00:20","updated":"2017-07-28 21:00:20","minute":"5:00 pm","short":"7\/28"},"authors":[{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"},{"id":19198150,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/olivier-laurent\/","name":"Olivier Laurent","bio":"Olivier Laurent is Editor of LightBox at TIME","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"olivierclaurent","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/olivierclaurent","gplus":"","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":null,"contributor":true,"search_link":false,"author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/olivier-laurent\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4592406\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4592406\/john-g-morris-100\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Robert Capa&#8217;s iconic 1944 shot of a soldier in the surf at Normandy would become one of the most celebrated pictures of the Second World War&mdash;but Capa did not act alone. John G. Morris, a picture editor at LIFE magazine, had assigned the war photographer to cover D-Day.<\/p>\n<p>The small number of pictures with which Capa returned, which Morris published in LIFE, <a href=\"http:\/\/100photos.time.com\/photos\/robert-capa-d-day\">became legendary<\/a>. But that was just the beginning for Morris. He went on to work at the New York <em>Times<\/em>, the Washington <em>Post<\/em>, National Geographic and Magnum Photos. He became a legend himself. He died on Friday at age 100, Robert Pledge of Contact Press Images confirmed to TIME.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=589\" data-attachment-id=\"4879235\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4592406\/john-g-morris-100\/john-morris-bayeux-normandy-july-23-1944-photographed-by-ned-buddy\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1901,2000\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;Exp10000XL10000&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;1369602729&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;\\u00a9 Collection John G. Morris (Contact Press Images)&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.\" data-image-description=\"pJohn Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy. The photograph was published in Morris\u2019 last book \u201cQuelque Part En France\u201d, Marabout\/Hachete published in 2014.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?quality=85&amp;w=285\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?quality=85&amp;w=570\" alt=\"John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.\" height=\"589\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4879235\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4592406\/john-g-morris-100\/john-morris-bayeux-normandy-july-23-1944-photographed-by-ned-buddy\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1901,2000\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"Exp10000XL10000\",\"caption\":\"John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1369602729\",\"copyright\":\"\\u00a9 Collection John G. Morris (Contact Press Images)\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.\" data-image-description=\"pJohn Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy. The photograph was published in Morris\u2019 last book \u201cQuelque Part En France\u201d, Marabout\/Hachete published in 2014.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?quality=85&w=285\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?quality=85&w=570\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/unknown-2.jpeg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=589\" alt=\"John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy.\" height=\"589\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Ned Buddy&mdash;Collection of John G. Morris\/Contact <\/span><span class=\"caption\" >John Morris, Bayeux, Normandy, July 23, 1944, photographed by Ned Buddy. The photograph was published in Morris&#8217; last book &#8220;Quelque Part En France&#8221;, Marabout\/Hachete published in 2014.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>&#8220;John&rsquo;s life was shaped by war. He was a child of the Great War and lived thorough WWII and Vietnam &mdash; and every other conflict until Iraq and Syria. He followed these conflicts as an observer and a humanist,&#8221; Pledge told TIME. &#8220;When I look back at what he did with his career, war was his primary concern &mdash; it framed his understanding of humanity. Human enlightenment and understanding were always his goals.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>In late 2016, as he celebrated his milestone birthday, we asked his friends and colleagues to reflect on his century. Here are those memories.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Russell Burrows, son of photojournalist Larry Burrows, with Barbara &#8220;Bobbie&#8221; Baker Burrows, a LIFE photo editor<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>For three quarters of his life, John has had to share the anniversary of his birth with that day of infamy. It&#8217;s a concurrence mentioned in several tributes to John and, certainly, the 7th of December should never be forgotten. But that&#8217;s a rather grim connection.<\/p>\n<p>It&#8217;s another day &mdash; famous too, and grim, but one that has ultimately come to be viewed much more positively &mdash; D-Day, that became central to John&#8217;s life. With the assignment of a team of great photographers to cover the invasion, and his own journey from wartime London to Normandy to Paris, John began a remarkable career. The stories that followed are oft-told and familiar to anyone with a knowledge of 20th century photography.<\/p>\n<p>Ten years younger than John, my father had been an office boy who eagerly became a photo lab technician in the LIFE London darkroom that was part of John&#8217;s domain. It was the beginning of what, through three generations, is now a long family friendship. (Who could have imagined that 60 years after those lab days, John would be accepting the Prix Nadar, for the photography book of the year, on my father&#8217;s behalf?)<\/p>\n<p>When Bobbi Baker joined LIFE in the 1960s, John was long gone from the magazine and well established as the picture editor of the New York <em>Times<\/em>. Just as illustrious, Richard O. Pollard was solidly in charge as LIFE&#8217;s director of photography. When Dick suggested that the <em>Times<\/em> had some photographs that LIFE needed and that &#8220;Johnny Morris over there&#8221; knew all about it, he told Bobbi to give him a call. The young photo researcher dutifully did so.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Johnny, we need those pictures.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>It wasn&#8217;t long before John made the delivery himself! Bobbi learned who John G. Morris was, and another connection was made between our families (she didn&#8217;t actually become a Burrows for a few more years).<\/p>\n<p>We&#8217;ve known John, his wives, his family, we know John&#8217;s politics (and he will passionately share them with anyone), but in the U.S., in Britain and in France, we&#8217;ve seen his influence on photography &mdash; and few can match it. Happy century John.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=560\" data-attachment-id=\"4592518\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4592406\/john-g-morris-100\/john-morris-birthday-100\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1030,1030\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;2.8&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;DMC-LX2&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;John Morris at the Vanity Fair exhibit,\\rNational Portrait Gallery, London\\r11 February 2008\\rPhotograph by Russell Burrows&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;1202748495&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;Photograph by Russell Burrows&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;6.3&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;100&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0.076923076923077&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"john-morris-birthday-100\" data-image-description=\"pJohn G. Morris at the Vanity Fair exhibit, National Portrait Gallery, London February 11, 2008.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=600\" alt=\"John G. Morris at the Vanity Fair exhibit, National Portrait Gallery, London February 11, 2008.\" height=\"560\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4592518\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4592406\/john-g-morris-100\/john-morris-birthday-100\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1030,1030\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"2.8\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"DMC-LX2\",\"caption\":\"John Morris at the Vanity Fair exhibit,\\rNational Portrait Gallery, London\\r11 February 2008\\rPhotograph by Russell Burrows\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1202748495\",\"copyright\":\"Photograph by Russell Burrows\",\"focal_length\":\"6.3\",\"iso\":\"100\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.076923076923077\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"john-morris-birthday-100\" data-image-description=\"pJohn G. Morris at the Vanity Fair exhibit, National Portrait Gallery, London February 11, 2008.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2016\/12\/john-morris-birthday-100.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=560\" alt=\"John G. Morris at the Vanity Fair exhibit, National Portrait Gallery, London February 11, 2008.\" height=\"560\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Russell Burrows<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >John G. Morris at the Vanity Fair exhibit, National Portrait Gallery, London February 11, 2008.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p><strong>David Friend, creative development editor at Vanity Fair and a former LIFE director of photography<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>John Morris has been the Zelig, the Svengali, the Rasputin, the Diaghilev, the Bob Fosse, the Vince Lombardi of 20th century photojournalism and humanistic photography.<\/p>\n<p>He honed his intellect at his beloved University of Chicago. He developed his journalistic instincts at LIFE. He became an entrepreneur and herder of stray cats (and panthers) at Magnum. He stiffened his backbone at the New York <em>Times<\/em>. He has been the keeper of the flame of Robert and Cornell Capa, of W. Eugene Smith, of so many other giants of the medium.<\/p>\n<p>No living picture editor has been involved behind the scenes in the creation of more famous photographs over a longer span of time. And, from his post in Paris, he remains a dedicated defender of American liberalism in a rising sea of intolerance.<\/p>\n<p>Hats off to John; to his friends and wives no longer with us; to the FIRST hundred years.<\/p>\n<div class=\"video-container\"><video id=\"brightcove-player-4509408555001\" data-video-id=\"4509408555001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"><\/video><\/div>\n<p><strong>Jean-Francois Leroy, director of the Visa pour l&#8217;Image photojournalism festival<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>John G. Morris is this kind of guy you&#8217;re always impressed to meet. He had a friend called Robert Capa. Another called Henri Cartier-Bresson. So, like everybody else, I was really intimidated during our first meeting. But he is so generous, he tells you all of the stories you&#8217;ve always wanted to hear. He&#8217;s a living memory and such a good friend!<\/p>\n<p>I have had the privilege to have another friend, one year older than John: David Douglas Duncan. Both of them are proof that this photo field is a very good way to have a long life!<\/p>\n<p>One day, at a print auction for the French photographer Fran&ccedil;oise Demulder when she was sick, John put in one of his pictures. I bought it. A few years later, when he had his show in Perpignan, he signed it: &#8220;To my first customer.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p><strong>Robert Sullivan, editor of LIFE Books from 1990 to 2015<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>In my years at LIFE in the 1990s and into this decade, I got to meet and, in certain cases, to know some legends: Eisie, Carl, David, Martha, Gordon, Harry, Henry, Bill and on. <span class=\"s1\">John&mdash;Loengard, who I still know, but also Morris&mdash;was a legend, but I never met him (the Morris, John); <\/span>But who could not be intrigued and inspired by John&rsquo;s career, success, and dedication? I learned from my colleague Bobbi, whom you&rsquo;ve heard from here, that he is the best kind of person. I heard that from others, too. I don&rsquo;t doubt it.<\/p>\n<p>As John turns 100, I couldn&rsquo;t be happier&mdash;I&rsquo;ve been rooting for John and David [Douglas Duncan] for a couple of years now&mdash;and I think the one thing I can say about John is, with LIFE, I always wanted to do away with the myths. People&mdash;those damned media people&mdash;always called wanting to know who kissed the nurse and how Capa&rsquo;s D-Day film distilled to so few images, among other things. I referred folks to Loudon&rsquo;s terrific book, or if pressed, said, &ldquo;no.&rdquo; Eisie didn&rsquo;t take notes, of course he didn&rsquo;t. A former nurse just died this year, in 2016, and got national obits as THE ONE in the photo. She may well have been. Or you could have been. And it doesn&rsquo;t matter. The sailor and the nurse were intended as universals, and they are best seen that way. Elise never said who was who, and surely Eisie never knew.<\/p>\n<p>John Morris was a young man working for us, which is to say LIFE and TIME Inc., in London when Capa&rsquo;s cobbled shipment arrived from the front lines in Normandy. I firmly believe that John developed capably what images could be capably developed. Everyone was in a hurry. There&rsquo;s no scandal here. We in the U.S. are in a season of scandal-mongering about every little thing, and I reflect that historically there are lots of &ldquo;scandals&rdquo; that have attached themselves to our&mdash;to LIFE&rsquo;s&mdash;story (again: go to Loudon&rsquo;s book for clarity).<\/p>\n<p>Yes the images look shaky, and that&rsquo;s part of their power. Was that a product of bombs on the beach or emulsions in London? If the latter, history&mdash;not to mention Mr. Spielberg&mdash;owes John Morris a greater debt. He took us there, not as much as Capa did, but he played his part.<\/p>\n<p>Happy birthday, John. I do hope we meet down the road.<\/p>\n<p><strong>John Loengard, a photographer and picture editor at LIFE<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>John G. Morris is truly a gentleman. Our relationship over the years has been pleasant but only on brief and tangential meetings. I met him first when he was managing Magnum in the mid-1950s. His unwavering belief in the value of journalism by camera impressed me then, and that conviction is as fresh in him today as it was 60 years ago. Bravo! And happy 100th birthday!<\/p>\n<p>&nbsp;<\/p>\n<p><em><strong>Liz Ronk<\/strong> is the History Photo Editor for TIME and LIFE.<\/em><\/p>\n<p><em><strong>Olivier Laurent <\/strong>is the editor of TIME LightBox. Morris","alt":"John G.
