Morris","description":"His friends and colleagues reflect on his century of influence on photography","google_news":"john g. morris, photography, life magazine, photo, photo editor, magnum photos, robert capa, birthday","keywords":"john g. morris, photography, life magazine, photo, photo editor, magnum photos, robert capa, birthday","og_title":"Celebrating Legendary LIFE Photo Editor John G. Morris","og_desc":"His friends and colleagues reflect on his century of influence on photography","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4858551\/friendship-day-photos\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2uZQi5y","title":"Celebrate Friendship With LIFE&#8217;s Most Memorable Pictures of Pals","friendly_title":"Celebrate Friendship With LIFE\u2019s Most Memorable Pictures of Pals","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"Celebrate Friendship With LIFE&#8217;s Most Memorable Pictures of Pals","excerpt":"See 25 of the most memorable images of friends\u2014famous and otherwise\u2014from LIFE Magazine's archive of iconic photography","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"July 28, 2017","published":"2017-07-28 09:00:07","updated":"2017-07-28 13:00:07","minute":"9:00 am","short":"7\/28"},"authors":[{"id":208191972,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/olivia-b-waxman\/","name":"Olivia B. Waxman","bio":"Olivia is a Staff Writer. An honors graduate of Columbia Journalism School and Hamilton College, she grew up in New York City.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"OBWax","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/OBWax","gplus":"107906059620632524688","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_1445.jpg?quality=85&crop=81px%2C115px%2C2671px%2C2671px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Olivia+B.+Waxman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/olivia-b-waxman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module ad-300-250\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4858551\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4858551\/friendship-day-photos\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Looking at this survey of 25 of the best photos of BFFs from LIFE Magazine&#8217;s archive of iconic 20th-century photography, one fact is immediately clear: whether you&#8217;re the biggest star in the world or just an average kid, a true friendship is easy to recognize. And if there&#8217;s any lesson from the pictures of headline-worthy individuals with their friends, it&#8217;s that there&#8217;s nothing like a day with a friend to make you let down your guard.<\/p>\n<p>For Rita Hayworth in 1940, that meant <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=1j8EAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA58&amp;dq=%22rita+hayworth%22+minerva&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiHotumhKjVAhVH2SYKHbDOBbwQ6AEILjAB#v=onepage&amp;q=%22rita%20hayworth%22%20minerva&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">packing up jelly sandwiches<\/a> for a bicycle picnic. For Lauren Bacall, it meant pictured gabbing with girlfriends in her hotel suite at the Gotham in Manhattan &mdash; a meaningful location, as LIFE <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=8UkEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA104&amp;dq=lauren+bacall+with+friends+at+the+gotham+hotel&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwi02Za1iqjVAhWH0iYKHbVLAxgQ6AEIJDAA#v=onepage&amp;q=gotham&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">explained<\/a> in 1945, because she and her friends had gone there as teens to gawk at celebrities. They had once followed Bette Davis into an elevator and had also been thrown out for trying to sneak into a party, which drove Bacall to announced that when <em>she<\/em> was famous, she would stay there. (&#8220;She not only did that when she and <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3852221\/bacall-bogart-wedding\/\">Bogart<\/a> came to New York in February,&#8221; the article noted, &#8220;but brought along her dog Droopy, an elderly spaniel, despite a house rule prohibiting dogs in the hotel.&#8221;) And for Jimmy Stewart, it meant returning to his roots, bass fishing with a friend in for a 1945 <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=3EkEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA126&amp;dq=%22jimmy+stewart%22&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjNmOqohqjVAhWIeCYKHfq0Bz4Q6AEIQDAG#v=onepage&amp;q=%22jimmy%20stewart%22&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">series<\/a> on the entertainer coming home to Indiana, Penn., after four years as an Army <a href=\"http:\/\/www.historynet.com\/mr-stewart-goes-to-war.htm\" target=\"_blank\">bomber pilot<\/a> during World War II. Jimmy &#8220;did not catch any fish but enjoyed himself anyway,&#8221; LIFE reported.<\/p>\n<p>And for renowned jazz musicians Dizzy Gillespie and Benny Carter, recognizing their friendship was even easier, thanks to a signature handshake, LIFE <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=dEoEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA138&amp;dq=gillespie+bebop+greeting&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiR8Oq1harVAhXJ4iYKHRZaBJsQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&amp;q=gillespie%20bebop%20greeting&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">noted<\/a> in 1948 was often imitated by the devotees of their music. Here are the steps, in case you want to practice with any of your close pals for the U.N.-designated <a href=\"http:\/\/www.un.org\/en\/events\/friendshipday\/\" target=\"_blank\">International Day of Friendship<\/a> on Sunday:<\/p>\n<figure class=\"image-wrapper no-caption\"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/screen-shot-2017-07-26-at-7-45-44-pm.png?w=560\" data-attachment-id=\"4875853\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4858551\/friendship-day-photos\/screen-shot-2017-07-26-at-7-45-44-pm\/\" 15:30:54","updated":"2017-07-26 19:30:54","minute":"3:30 pm","short":"7\/26"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lilyrothman","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lilyrothman","gplus":"115083326003510988963","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_2552.jpg?quality=85&crop=364px%2C105px%2C2338px%2C2337px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Lily+Rothman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/lily-rothman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4816856\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4816856\/pittsburgh-steel-worker-families\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Even as it has largely <a href=\"http:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2009\/01\/08\/business\/economy\/08collapse.html?mcubz=1\" target=\"_blank\">moved on<\/a> from the heyday of the industry, Pittsburgh &mdash; thanks in part to its football team &mdash; retains its link to the glory days of American steel.<\/p>\n<p>In LIFE&#8217;s vast archives of photography, one side of that history is captured vividly in these photographs by Wallace Kirkland, a LIFE staff photographer who made the images above in May of 1944. While the photos survived, very little information remains about the people and places they show.<\/p>\n<p>Such situations are not uncommon when it comes to LIFE. Photographers like Kirkland were dispatched all around the world but, especially amid the fast-paced news climate of World War II, even the most striking photojournalism could be bumped out of the magazine by more pressing news. The staff did a generally excellent job of archiving the captions and reporters&#8217; notes that were sent back by the people who worked on the stories, but things fell through the cracks, and that incarnation of the magazine <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3503080\/the-best-of-life-37-years-in-pictures\/\">ceased<\/a> production in 1972. The images in the collection are still available and can be searched, but when they come back with sparse captions and no notes, today&#8217;s reporters are stuck. Sometimes outside clues can be used to identify the content of the images &mdash; last year, we even <a href=\"https:\/\/time.com\/4158994\/llama-kangaroo-party-photos\/\">identified a llama<\/a> &mdash; but not always.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>This Pittsburgh family appears to fall into that latter, unfortunate category. Kirkland died in 1979 and his 1954 memoir contains no mention of Pittsburgh.<\/p>\n<p>What we can say is that there would have been plenty of news to cover in Pittsburgh at the time. During the World War II era, the state of Pennsylvania was responsible for <a href=\"http:\/\/explorepahistory.com\/story.php?storyId=1-9-19&amp;chapter=3\" target=\"_blank\">nearly a third<\/a> of American steel production. With many citizens off to fight abroad, the need for workers was high. The year 1944 ought to have been a high point for steel workers: though the end of the war in 1945 would bring fear of <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=pd7yEHZ76TUC&amp;pg=PA283&amp;dq=pittsburgh+1944+steel&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjXvu-31ZXVAhVLwiYKHVBzDWkQ6AEIKjAB#v=onepage&amp;q=1944&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">scaled back<\/a> production and fewer jobs, the previous year saw high demand. (<a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=pd7yEHZ76TUC&amp;pg=PA283&amp;dq=pittsburgh+1944+steel&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjXvu-31ZXVAhVLwiYKHVBzDWkQ6AEIKjAB#v=onepage&amp;q=1944&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">Military contracts<\/a> were a source of much money.) Women as well as men went to work in the steel industry. But amid that boom, the steel industry felt the privations of war. In order to prevent inflation, the War Labor Board put a limit on raises, even as the cost of living increased.<\/p>\n<p>The terminology used in the extant captions (the &#8220;slum area&#8221; and the &#8220;dirty kitchen&#8221;) implies that these images were taken for a story about poverty, and perhaps this family was an example of the people who were affected by those limits on pay. We also know that Kirkland, who had a degree in social work administration and had <a href=\"http:\/\/articles.chicagotribune.com\/1989-09-22\/entertainment\/8901150389_1_dance-classes-charles-hull-life-magazine\" target=\"_blank\">worked in Chicago at the Hull-House<\/a> settlement prior to joining LIFE&#8217;s staff, was experienced in using his camera to capture the lives of the disadvantaged and marginalized.<\/p>\n<p>In the post-war years, <a href=\"time.com\/vault\/issue\/1949-10-03\/page\/13\/\">redevelopment<\/a> in Pittsburgh &mdash; home of <a href=\"https:\/\/www.citylab.com\/design\/2012\/06\/what-pittsburgh-looked-when-it-decided-it-had-pollution-problem\/2185\/\" target=\"_blank\">infamously<\/a> bad air quality &mdash; led to the destruction of large areas of working-class housing (particularly African-American neighborhoods, apparently not visited by Kirkland).<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;For nearly a century and a half the metropolis had developed as an industrial slum,&#8221; LIFE noted in a <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=p0wEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA2&amp;lpg=PA2&amp;dq=%22wallace+kirkland%22+pittsburgh&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=cw2xluS6db&amp;sig=LF-XiwJmeI3yYyF-A7YmckDCtJA&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjFvobb0pXVAhUB4yYKHSEiCFsQ6AEIQzAL#v=onepage&amp;q=%22wallace%20kirkland%22%20pittsburgh&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">1<\/a><a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=p0wEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA2&amp;lpg=PA2&amp;dq=%22wallace+kirkland%22+pittsburgh&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=cw2xluS6db&amp;sig=LF-XiwJmeI3yYyF-A7YmckDCtJA&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjFvobb0pXVAhUB4yYKHSEiCFsQ6AEIQzAL#v=onepage&amp;q=%22wallace%20kirkland%22%20pittsburgh&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">956 story<\/a> about efforts to rebuild the city. &#8220;Smothering under its black smoke shroud, it had been squalid, sooty and tired. At the end of World War II, with real estate values fallen and its people and its industries craving to move elsewhere, Pittsburgh had seemed incurably ill.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>Recently, Pittsburgh&#8217;s economy has been doing <a href=\"http:\/\/www.phillymag.com\/business\/2017\/04\/29\/pittsburgh-philadelphia-tech-innovation\/\" target=\"_blank\">fairly well<\/a>, with many <a href=\"http:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2009\/01\/08\/business\/economy\/08collapse.html?mcubz=1\" target=\"_blank\">former steel workers<\/a> entering new industries that seem to show greater hope for the future.<\/p>\n<p><em>Do you recognize the people or places seen in these photographs? If so, we&#8217;d love to hear more about them. Find us on Twitter at @LIFE.<\/em><\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Waxman","bio":"Olivia is a Staff Writer. An honors graduate of Columbia Journalism School and Hamilton College, she grew up in New York City.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"OBWax","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/OBWax","gplus":"107906059620632524688","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_1445.jpg?quality=85&crop=81px%2C115px%2C2671px%2C2671px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Olivia+B.+Waxman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/olivia-b-waxman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4864460\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4864460\/dunkirk-evacuation-photos\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Though the characters in Christopher Nolan&#8217;s new film <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4864051\/dunkirk-review\"><em>Dunkirk<\/em><\/a> are fictional, the events among which they find themselves are based on a very real moment in World War II history, and the daring rescue of British forces who had reached a point of no return after fleeing from a German blitz in May of 1940. Relatively few photographs made it out of <a href=\"http:\/\/ti.me\/2ubwWvJ\" target=\"_blank\">Operation Dynamo <\/a>but it&#8217;s clear from what does exist &mdash; a sampling of which can be seen above &mdash; that those days in Dunkirk were harrowing ones.<\/p>\n<p>And, though photographic and video documentation of the real events may be sparse, some of the actual artifacts of that time have been well preserved. For example, some of the most memorable scenes in the film involve <a href=\"http:\/\/www.mirror.co.uk\/tv\/tv-reviews\/dunkirk-review-tom-hardy-soars-10777042\" target=\"_blank\">Tom Hardy as a Spitfire pilot sparring with Germans <\/a>and the &#8220;little ships&#8221; that helped to rescue British forces &mdash; one such real Spitfire plane and little ship can be found in the collection of the <a href=\"http:\/\/www.iwm.org.uk\/\" target=\"_blank\">Imperial War Museums,<\/a> from whose collection the archival video footage below is also taken.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<div class=\"video-container\"><video id=\"brightcove-player-5512887106001\" data-video-id=\"5512887106001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"><\/video><\/div>\n<figure class=\"inline-inline_small alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?w=190&#038;quality=85&#038;h=315\" data-attachment-id=\"4864479\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4864460\/dunkirk-evacuation-photos\/ship-fishing-boat-tamzine-british\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"482,800\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" Fishing Boat British Clinker-built wooden-hulled open fishing equipped with and removable centre The vessel was designed for year-round off the Birchington Copyright: Original Source: IWM data-image-title=\"Tamzine \u2013 Dunkirk\" data-image-description=\"pTamzine was the smallest vessel to participate in the Dunkirk evacuation and is now on display at IWM London. Originally intended to be a fishing boat, Tamzine was requisitioned for use in Operation Dynamo, the evacuation of the BEF from the beaches of Dunkirk, 27 May \u00e2&#128;&#147; 4 June 1940.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=181\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=362\" alt=\"Tamzine was the smallest vessel to participate in the Dunkirk evacuation and is now on display at IWM London. Originally intended to be a fishing boat, Tamzine was requisitioned for use in Operation Dynamo, the evacuation of the BEF from the beaches of Dunkirk, 27 May &acirc;&#128;&#147; 4 June 1940.\" height=\"315\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4864479\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4864460\/dunkirk-evacuation-photos\/ship-fishing-boat-tamzine-british\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"482,800\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"Ship, Fishing Boat 'Tamzine', British (MAR 556) Clinker-built wooden-hulled open fishing boat, equipped with sails, and with removable centre thwart. The vessel was designed for year-round fishing off the Birchington Shore. Copyright: \\u00a9 IWM. Original Source: http:\\\/\\\/www.iwm.org.uk\\\/collections\\\/item\\\/object\\\/30004026\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\\u00a9 IWM (MAR 556)\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"Ship, Fishing Boat 'Tamzine', British\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}\" data-image-title=\"Tamzine \u2013 Dunkirk\" data-image-description=\"pTamzine was the smallest vessel to participate in the Dunkirk evacuation and is now on display at IWM London. Originally intended to be a fishing boat, Tamzine was requisitioned for use in Operation Dynamo, the evacuation of the BEF from the beaches of Dunkirk, 27 May \u00e2&#128;&#147; 4 June 1940.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?quality=85&w=181\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?quality=85&w=362\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-little-boat.jpg?w=190&#038;quality=85&#038;h=315\" alt=\"Tamzine was the smallest vessel to participate in the Dunkirk evacuation and is now on display at IWM London. Originally intended to be a fishing boat, Tamzine was requisitioned for use in Operation Dynamo, the evacuation of the BEF from the beaches of Dunkirk, 27 May &acirc;&#128;&#147; 4 June 1940.\" height=\"315\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Courtesy of Imperial War Museums<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >Tamzine was the smallest vessel to participate in the Dunkirk evacuation and is now on display at IWM London. <br \/> <\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>The<span class=\"caption\"> fishing boat pictured at left, Tamzine, was one of more than 1,000 &#8220;little ships&#8221; that civilians provided to ferry stranded men from the shallow beach at Dunkirk to the bigger Navy ships parked in a deeper part of the English Chanel between<\/span> May 26, 1940, to June 4, 1940. Midway through the evacuation, the Germans Luftwaffe carried out air raids &mdash; as if the rescue effort hadn&#8217;t already been harrowing enough &mdash; and the Spitfire pictured below was shot down on a French beach, where it was covered by sand and not dug up for about 50 years. (It was restored to good condition before being displayed.)<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small alignright \"><figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Courtesy of Imperial War Museums<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >This Spitfire flew its first and only mission at Dunkirk &ndash; after shooting down an enemy dive-bomber, the Spitfire was itself shot down and crash landed on a French beach.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>John Delaney, one of the museum&#8217;s experts on the collection, explains that at that point in the war, the British armed forces hadn&rsquo;t gotten together an effective system of propaganda newsreels. As a result, news cameraman Charles Martin of the news agency Path&eacute; is said to have been the only one documenting the event, and because when he joined in to help with the evacuation there are few photos in general of the operation.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;All these guys were abandoning everything they had, any worldly possessions, to get on the boat and get out, because they didn&rsquo;t want the boats to get weighed down with their cameras,&#8221; says Delaney. &#8220;You&rsquo;d expect it&rsquo;d be the Army who would save the civilians, in this case it was the civilians who saved the Army.&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"History","slug":"history","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/history\/","description":"The news in context, from the archives of TIME. Evacuated","width":1934,"height":2405,"orientation":"square","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4864460\/dunkirk-evacuation-photos\/photo\/wwii-france-dunkirk-soldiers-evacuated\/","encoded_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4864460\/dunkirk-evacuation-photos\/photo\/wwii-france-dunkirk-soldiers-evacuated\/","twitter_via":"","encoded_title":"See+Harrowing+Footage+of+the+Real+Evacuation+of+Dunkirk+in+1940","encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4864460%2Fdunkirk-evacuation-photos%2Fphoto%2Fwwii-france-dunkirk-soldiers-evacuated%2F","twitter_encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4864460%2Fdunkirk-evacuation-photos%2Fphoto%2Fwwii-france-dunkirk-soldiers-evacuated%2F","email_title":"See%20Harrowing%20Footage%20of%20the%20Real%20Evacuation%20of%20Dunkirk%20in%201940","twitter_text":"See%20harrowing%20images%20of%20the%20real%20evacuation%20of%20Dunkirk%20in%201940","fb_text":"See%20harrowing%20images%20of%20the%20real%20evacuation%20of%20Dunkirk%20in%201940","email_body":"See%20Harrowing%20Footage%20of%20the%20Real%20Evacuation%20of%20Dunkirk%20in%201940%0A%0ARelatively%20few%20photos%20exist%20of%20the%20real%20events%20behind%20the%20movie%2C%20but%20it%27s%20still%20clear%20from%20what%20does%20exist%20that%20those%20days%20were%20harrowing%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4864460%2Fdunkirk-evacuation-photos%2Fphoto%2Fwwii-france-dunkirk-soldiers-evacuated%2F","src":{"small":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-04.jpg?quality=85&w=217","small_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-04.jpg?quality=85&w=434","landscape_large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-04.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-04.jpg?quality=85&w=217","large_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-dunkirk-04.jpg?quality=85&w=450","square":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/battle-of-du See Footage and Photos of Real WWII Evacuation","description":"Relatively few photos exist of the real events behind the movie, but it's still clear from what does exist that those days were harrowing.","google_news":"dunkirk, dunkirk movie, is dunkirk real, is dunkirk a true story, christopher nolan, dunkirk story, dunkirk photos, dunkirk battle, dunkirk history, dunkirk harrowing","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4848976\/newark-riots-1967-photographer\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2uSfPwJ","title":"What One Photographer Saw During the Deadly Newark Riots of 1967","friendly_title":"What One Photographer Saw During the Deadly Newark Riots of 1967","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"What One Photographer Saw During the Deadly Newark Riots of 1967","excerpt":"A LIFE magazine cover story boasted of unparalleled access to those behind the riot, but it would take longer for the full story to emerge","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"July 12, 2017","published":"2017-07-12 09:30:07","updated":"2017-07-12 13:30:07","minute":"9:30 am","short":"7\/12"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lilyrothman","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lilyrothman","gplus":"115083326003510988963","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_2552.jpg?quality=85&crop=364px%2C105px%2C2338px%2C2337px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Lily+Rothman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/lily-rothman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4848976\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4848976\/newark-riots-1967-photographer\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>It wasn&#8217;t easy to tell the story of the rioting that broke out 50 years ago Wednesday in Newark, N.J., and continued over several chaotic and destructive days during which more than two dozen people were killed.<\/p>\n<p>As the <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=1lUEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PP1&amp;pg=PP1#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">editors&#8217; note<\/a> in the issue of LIFE magazine dedicated to the riots explained, the photographers and reporters who had been sent to cover the news &#8220;faced danger and death in the riot-torn city, ducking sniper fire, skirting angry mobs, wondering if the jittery Guardsmen and trigger-happy police might not next open up on them.&#8221; LIFE devoted particular attention to the sniper fire, which was widely &mdash; and as it turns out, erroneously &mdash; believed at the time to have been directed toward law enforcement.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Despite the danger and challenges on the ground, LIFE&#8217;s journalists &mdash; among them Frank Dandridge, the photographer behind the images seen in this slideshow &mdash; got access to a side of the story that might otherwise have gone unseen, as the editors&#8217; note explained:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>In the midst of the violence we were able to make contact with one of Newark&#8217;s Black Nationalist leaders. Our request: to photograph one of the elusive snipers. After much consultation Photographer Frank Dandridge, who is a Negro, was led through the streets to an abandoned tenement, up four flights of stairs and into a front room where he was allowed to take the picture of page 17 [seen in the third slide above].<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>For all of its emphasis on the role of snipers, the magazine&#8217;s reporting hinted at what we now know to be true: the fear of organized snipers among the rioters was unfounded. Indeed, the story accompanying Dandridge&#8217;s images noted that &#8220;it was puzzling why so few police and Guardsmen were hit&#8221; if such gunmen were really active in the area. And, when Dandridge was taken to a &#8220;clandestine meeting&#8221; on the &#8220;outskirts of the riot zone,&#8221; the men he met there told him that while they had given up on nonviolence as a concept, they were not in fact shooting at people. Instead, they used the sound of gunfire to influence where the police went during the rioting. &#8220;Five or six shots in the air are enough to draw cops thick as fleas on a dog,&#8221; one told the magazine.<\/p>\n<p>By 1968, those hints in LIFE were confirmed in the official <a href=\"https:\/\/www.ncjrs.gov\/pdffiles1\/Digitization\/8073NCJRS.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">report<\/a> of the presidential commission appointed to investigate the matter. The policemen and Guardsmen present <em>believed<\/em> that they were under fire from snipers, the commission found, but after three hours of searching during which &#8220;four truckloads of National Guardsmen had arrived and troopers and policemen were again crouched everywhere looking for a sniper&#8221; the only actual gunshot came from law enforcement. And, the report continued, the belief that snipers were nearby led the Guardsmen and state troopers to direct &#8220;mass fire&#8221; at a housing project, killing several bystanders.<\/p>\n<p>The heavy emphasis on sniper fire in LIFE&#8217;s coverage of the events in Newark may not reflect an accurate retelling of what happened, but the story remains valuable for how it sheds light on the widely circulating misinformation of the time &mdash; and Dandridge&#8217;s photographs remain as stirring as ever.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x alignnone \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-riot-1967-cover.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=725\" data-attachment-id=\"4849032\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4848976\/newark-riots-1967-photographer\/life_july_28_1967-jpg\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-riot-1967-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1857,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;BUD LEE&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;LIFE cover 7-28-1967: Newark: The Unpredicable Insurrection. Peterson.","width":2405,"height":1616,"orientation":"square","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4848976\/newark-riots-1967-photographer\/photo\/newark-life-spreads-05\/","encoded_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4848976\/newark-riots-1967-photographer\/photo\/newark-life-spreads-05\/","twitter_via":"","encoded_title":"What+One+Photographer+Saw+During+the+Deadly+Newark+Riots+of+1967","encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4848976%2Fnewark-riots-1967-photographer%2Fphoto%2Fnewark-life-spreads-05%2F","twitter_encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4848976%2Fnewark-riots-1967-photographer%2Fphoto%2Fnewark-life-spreads-05%2F","email_title":"What%20One%20Photographer%20Saw%20During%20the%20Deadly%20Newark%20Riots%20of%201967","twitter_text":"What%20one%20photographer%20saw%20during%20rioting%20in%20Newark%20in%201967","fb_text":"What%20one%20photographer%20saw%20during%20rioting%20in%20Newark%20in%201967","email_body":"What%20One%20Photographer%20Saw%20During%20the%20Deadly%20Newark%20Riots%20of%201967%0A%0AA%20LIFE%20magazine%20cover%20story%20boasted%20of%20unparalleled%20access%20to%20those%20behind%20the%20riot%2C%20but%20it%20would%20take%20longer%20for%20the%20full%20story%20to%20emerge%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4848976%2Fnewark-riots-1967-photographer%2Fphoto%2Fnewark-life-spreads-05%2F","src":{"small":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-life-spreads-05.jpg?quality=85&w=402","small_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-life-spreads-05.jpg?quality=85&w=804","landscape_large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-life-spreads-05.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-life-spreads-05.jpg?quality=85&w=402","large_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-life-spreads-05.jpg?quality=85&w=832","square":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/07\/newark-life-spreads-05.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1","fullsc 100 and the Story Behind His Most Famous Painting","friendly_title":"Andrew Wyeth at 100 and the Story Behind His Most Famous Painting","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"Andrew Wyeth at 100 and the Story Behind His Most Famous Painting","excerpt":"At first, he believed his most famous painting would be as successful as \"a flat tire\"","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"July 12, 2017","published":"2017-07-12 09:00:54","updated":"2017-07-12 13:00:54","minute":"9:00 am","short":"7\/12"},"authors":[{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4840031\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4840031\/andrew-wyeth-at-100-and-the-story-behind-his-most-famous-painting\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p style=\"text-align:center;\"><em>&ldquo;If there is such a thing as a purely American tradition in Art, it is represented at its best in the straightforward canvases of Andrew Wyeth.&rdquo;<\/em><br \/>\n<em> &mdash; LIFE magazine, <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=HkYEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PP1&amp;pg=PA102#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">May 17, 1948<\/a><\/em><\/p>\n<p>By the time he turned 30, Andrew Wyeth had already cemented himself as one of the most important and quintessential American artists of his time. Born a full century ago in Chadds Ford, Penn., on July 12, 1917, Wyeth&#8217;s only formal education in art came from his father, Newell Convers &ldquo;N.C.&rdquo; Wyeth, who was an accomplished illustrator in his own right. When LIFE profiled the younger Wyeth in 1948, he was well along in his career, having sold out his first solo exhibition at the Macbeth Gallery in New York City a decade prior. His most famous painting, <em>Christina&rsquo;s World<\/em>, was painted the same year the 1948 article appeared in LIFE, but is not mentioned.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=187\" data-attachment-id=\"4842283\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4840031\/andrew-wyeth-at-100-and-the-story-behind-his-most-famous-painting\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1184,792\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine\" data-image-description=\"pChristina\u2019s World by Andrew Wyeth featured in the May 14, 1965 issue of LIFE magazine.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=600\" alt=\"Christina&#039;s World by Andrew Wyeth featured in the May 14, 1965 issue of LIFE magazine.\" height=\"187\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4842283\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4840031\/andrew-wyeth-at-100-and-the-story-behind-his-most-famous-painting\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1184,792\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine\" data-image-description=\"pChristina\u2019s World by Andrew Wyeth featured in the May 14, 1965 issue of LIFE magazine.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/christinas-world-wyeth-life-magazine.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=187\" alt=\"Christina's World by Andrew Wyeth featured in the May 14, 1965 issue of LIFE magazine.\" height=\"187\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >LIFE Magazine<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >Christina&#8217;s World by Andrew Wyeth featured in the May 14, 1965 issue of LIFE magazine.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>LIFE would feature Wyeth, who died in 2009, and his paintings many times over the years, including extensive articles in <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=YEIEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PP1&amp;pg=PA80#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">1953<\/a> and a <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=QFMEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PA5&amp;pg=PA92#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">1965<\/a> profile that featured 22 pages of his favorite paintings and a first-person interview by Richard Meryman, who became a good friend of Wyeth&#8217;s and went on to write a <a href=\"http:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/1997\/01\/17\/books\/an-imperfect-american-idol-and-his-self-enclosed-art.html\" target=\"_blank\">biography<\/a> of the painter.<\/p>\n<p>Of his most famous painting, which now hangs in the Museum of Modern Art in New York, Wyeth said, &ldquo;When I first painted it in 1948, <em>Christina&rsquo;s World<\/em> hung all summer in my house in Maine and nobody particularly reacted to it. I thought, &#8216;Boy, is this one ever a flat tire.'&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>TIME Magazine, however, had a different take on the painting in<a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/vault\/issue\/1963-12-27\/page\/44\/\"> a cover story <\/a>on Wyeth in 1963, calling the work, &ldquo;One of the most durable and disquieting images of 20th century America,&#8221; and explaining the story behind the picture:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>The most famous of these [subjects] is a woman named Christina Olson. He has painted eight temperas of her or her house, a decrepit three-story clapboard pile atop a knoll near the Maine seacoast. One of them, <em>Christina&#8217;s World<\/em>, now 15 years old, is one of the most durable and disquieting images of 20th century America. Against the wall of landscape that leads up to her house, the crippled body of an ageless woman seems trapped, imprisoned by the very emptiness of the earth. Manhattan&#8217;s Museum of Modern Art, which hesitated before buying it in 1948 for $2,200, has repaid its investment 22 times over in the sale of reproductions.<\/p>\n<p>Christina, who is <span class=\"highlight\">crippled<\/span> <span class=\"highlight\">by<\/span> <span class=\"highlight\">polio<\/span>, is one of Wyeth&#8217;s few close friends. He judges people by their reactions to her. &#8220;I don&#8217;t take some people to see her,&#8221; says Wyeth, &#8220;because they won&#8217;t understand.&#8221; He fears that they will find her grotesque. Christina&#8217;s house contains the anonymous leavings of years of confinement. The smell of burning oil, charred wood, fat cats and old cloth fills the air. Christina, now nearing 70, does not let anyone see how she moves about, stubbornly refuses to use a wheelchair. &#8220;Andy&#8217;s a very good friend,&#8221; she says. &#8220;I like to pose for him. He talks a great deal when he paints, but he doesn&#8217;t talk nonsense.&#8221; She does not talk nonsense either. Despite her painful loneliness, she is dignified, proud and intelligent.<\/p>\n<p>None of Wyeth&#8217;s portraits of Christina look alike; the artist injects his own humanity into the people and places around him. More than anything else that Wyeth paints, Christina&#8217;s individuality and inner strength are a mirror-portrait of the artist himself. She is a touchstone of his compassion.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small alignright \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=376\" data-attachment-id=\"4840048\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4840031\/andrew-wyeth-at-100-and-the-story-behind-his-most-famous-painting\/time-covers-the-60s-2\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1791,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;TIME MAGAZINE, COPYRIGHT TIME IN&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;TIME cover 12-27-1963 Portrait of artist Andrew Wyeth done by his sister, Henriette Hurd.&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;-189820800&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;TIME MAGAZINE, COPYRIGHT TIME IN&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;TIME COVERS - THE 60S&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"TIME Magazine Andrew Wyeth Cover\" data-image-description=\"pDec. 27, 1963 TIME magazine cover with painting of artist Andrew Wyeth by his sister Henriette Hurd.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=223\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=447\" alt=\"Dec. 27, 1963 TIME magazine cover with painting of artist Andrew Wyeth by his sister Henriette Hurd.\" height=\"376\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4840048\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4840031\/andrew-wyeth-at-100-and-the-story-behind-his-most-famous-painting\/time-covers-the-60s-2\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1791,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"TIME MAGAZINE, COPYRIGHT TIME IN\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"TIME cover 12-27-1963 Portrait of artist Andrew Wyeth done by his sister, Henriette Hurd.\",\"created_timestamp\":\"-189820800\",\"copyright\":\"TIME MAGAZINE, COPYRIGHT TIME IN\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"TIME COVERS - THE 60S\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"TIME Magazine Andrew Wyeth Cover\" data-image-description=\"pDec. 27, 1963 TIME magazine cover with painting of artist Andrew Wyeth by his sister Henriette Hurd.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=223\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=447\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/andrew-wyeth-time-magazine-cover.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=376\" alt=\"Dec. 27, 1963 TIME magazine cover with painting of artist Andrew Wyeth by his sister Henriette Hurd.\" height=\"376\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >TIME Magazine<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >Dec. 27, 1963 TIME magazine cover with painting of artist Andrew Wyeth by his sister Henriette Hurd. <\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>When it came to a portrait of Wyeth himself, however, TIME turned for its cover image to a different artist: his sister, Henriette Wyeth Hurd. The magazine also noted that <em>Her Room<\/em> (seen in the fourth slide in this gallery) had fetched the highest price paid by any museum for a work by a living artist at the time. The painting sold for $65,000.<\/p>\n<p>In Celebration of Wyeth&rsquo;s centennial, <a href=\"http:\/\/www.farnsworthmuseum.org\/exhibition\/andrew-wyeth-maine-watercolors-1938-to-2008\/\" target=\"_blank\">The Farnsworth Museum<\/a> in Rockland, Maine &mdash; which purchased Wyeth works from that 1944 Macbeth gallery show four years before the museum even opened to the public &mdash; is hosting a series of five exhibitions including a major watercolor show, <em>Andrew Wyeth at 100, <\/em>which runs through this year. Seen above is a small sampling of this comprehensive look at Wyeth&rsquo;s work spanning his entire career from 1938 through 2008.<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"History","slug":"history","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/history\/","description":"The news in context, from the archives of TIME. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module ad-300-250\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4835452\"><\/div><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Sometimes you need a reason to give another person a <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4670016\/kisses-history-video\/\">kiss.<\/a> And, as was the case in probably the <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4486812\/wwii-kiss-photo-vj-day\/\">most famous kissing photo of all time<\/a>, that reason can be a big one (victory in World War II). But, other times, a kiss is its own <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/65708\/a-kiss-is-more-than-just-a-kiss-elliott-erwitts-portraits-of-intimacy\/\">reason<\/a> to celebrate.<\/p>\n<p>Whatever you want to call it &mdash; a peck, a smooch, a snog &mdash; a kiss communicates love in a way that few other acts can match. How people started kissing is a <a href=\"http:\/\/healthland.time.com\/2011\/02\/11\/the-science-of-smooching-why-men-and-women-kiss-differently\/\">mystery<\/a> and why we do it is <a href=\"http:\/\/healthland.time.com\/2013\/10\/11\/why-good-looking-people-like-kissing-more\/\">complicated<\/a>, but, from a child&#8217;s sweet kiss to a lover&#8217;s sexy kiss (or a walrus&#8217; whiskery one, as the case may be), the act is a language of its own. And a photograph of a kiss, it follows, captures that feeling.<\/p>\n<p>Here, with a look back at 40 years of kisses from LIFE Magazine&#8217;s archives of iconic 20th century photography, that fact is as clear as ever.<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's New","friendly_title":"Coal Country\u2019s Suffering Is Nothing New","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"Coal Country&#8217;s Suffering Is Nothing New","excerpt":"In 1959, LIFE Magazine exposed the grim reality of life in the American coal industry","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"June 30, 2017","published":"2017-06-30 11:00:30","updated":"2017-06-30 15:00:30","minute":"11:00 am","short":"6\/30"},"authors":[{"id":243888282,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/justin-worland\/","name":"Justin Worland","bio":"Justin Worland is a New York-based writer for TIME covering energy and the environment.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"justinworland","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/justinworland","gplus":"","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/12\/justin-worland.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":false,"author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/justin-worland\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4820537\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4820537\/coal-country-unemployment-history\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Coal and the people who mine it have exploded onto the <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/coals-last-kick\/\">public consciousness<\/a> since the election of President Donald Trump last fall. Trump <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4447586\/trump-coal-industry-energy\/\">promised<\/a> to <a href=\"http:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/us-usa-trump-climate-power-idUSKBN1770D8\" target=\"_blank\">end<\/a> what he described as an Obama-era &#8220;war on coal.&#8221; On the campaign trail and on Thursday he said that the rough conditions coal miners face would be turned around by a new era of American &ldquo;energy dominance.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<p>&ldquo;You&rsquo;ve gone through eight years of hell,&rdquo; Trump <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4839884\/energy-dominance-energy-independence-donald-trump\/\">said<\/a>. But &ldquo;we have finally ended the war on coal.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<p>But, despite the rhetoric, suffering in coal country is not a new phenomenon.<\/p>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div>\n<p>Coal production has generally ramped up steadily since the conclusion of World War II, with an occasional downturn. But during the same time period the number of people employed by the industry has declined dramatically, as machines have replaced humans and engineers have invented more efficient ways to mine coal.<\/p>\n<p>Images <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=VkgEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PP1&amp;pg=PA34#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">published in LIFE Magazine in 1959<\/a> captured what to date remains the most precipitous sustained downturn for coal mining employment: the period between World War II and the early 1960s. During that time the number of coal employees fell from nearly 400,000 to less than 150,000 following the widespread adoption of new job-killing technology. Notes from the LIFE archive describe the coal loader &mdash; the most significant development leading to a decline in jobs at the time &mdash; as having &#8220;mechanical arms&#8221; that &#8220;resemble the action of the claws of a giant crab.&#8221; The machine could load 225 tons of coal in one hour, according to the notes.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;You have an industry that&rsquo;s very, very productive,&#8221; says William Gorby, a researcher at West Virginia University who studies Appalachian History, of mechanization. &#8220;But it&rsquo;s not employing that many people.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>As LIFE highlighted at the time, programs did exist to help mine workers relocate from economically depressed regions, but they were often greeted by workers with reluctance &mdash; even though a tough life awaited those who stayed. In Beckley, W.V., a fifth of the county, or 10,000 people, received surplus food from a single distribution center, according to notes from the LIFE archive. Children often went to school malnourished.<\/p>\n<p>The coal industry continued to improve in productivity in the following decades as mechanization continued and mine companies began a practice called surface mining, which is more efficient and requires fewer employees.<\/p>\n<p>That reality&mdash; having been joined by a <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4570070\/donald-trump-coal-jobs\/\">slew of other pressures<\/a>, most significantly competition from cheap natural gas &mdash; continues to this day.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x alignnone \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/coal-country-life-magazine.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=384\" data-attachment-id=\"4820573\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4820537\/coal-country-unemployment-history\/coal-country-life-magazine\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/coal-country-life-magazine.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1298,890\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"LIFE Magzine April 13, 1959\" data-image-description=\"p\u201cA Grim Instance in Coal Country,\u201d from the April 13, 1959 issue of LIFE magazine.\/p\n\" Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4823900\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4823900\/canada-day-woodsman\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>As Saturday&#8217;s <a href=\"http:\/\/newsfeed.time.com\/2011\/07\/01\/happy-canada-day-test-your-northern-knowledge-with-our-canadian-trivia-quiz\/\">Canada Day<\/a> holiday marks the 150th anniversary of the July 1, 1867, act that created the <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4391217\/justin-trudeau-canada-day-eh\/\">dominion<\/a>, it&#8217;s an appropriate time to celebrate all things Canadian. Though TIME <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/vault\/issue\/1967-05-05\/page\/36\/\">once remarked<\/a> that Canada had sometimes suffered from something of an identity crisis, defining itself more by what it isn&#8217;t than by what it is, certain elements of the Canadian character have long stood out.<\/p>\n<p>The stereotypical Northern woodsman captures one side of that national idea. And, back in 1953, photographer Wallace Kirkland explored that archetype for LIFE Magazine, with a photo profile of the perfectly named Rock Robertson &mdash; &#8220;Strong Man of the North,&#8221; <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=JUgEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PA171&amp;dq=strong%20man%20of%20the%20north&amp;pg=PA170#v=onepage&amp;q=strong%20man%20of%20the%20north&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">per the article&#8217;s headline.<\/a><br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Rock, at 31, six feet tall and 205 lbs., got his name from a grandfather who, in turn, acquired the nickname thanks to his strength. As a professional hunting and fishing guide, he regularly carried 300 pounds at a time for miles and could pull off a moose mating call good enough to draw in the bulls that hunters wanted most. He once went more than a week without food, thanks to a storm, before walking 48 miles in snowshoes to get out of the woods. He faced the forest with a smile and a shrug, embracing the outdoors lifestyle his ancestors &mdash; whether the French-Canadian, First Nations or Scottish ones &mdash; had likewise lived.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" >LIFE photographer Wallace Kirkland and Canadian woodsman Robert Rock, as he cleans a trout.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>&#8220;He has been known, when the mood takes him, to pick up a stove and heave it through a cook-shack wall,&#8221; the article noted. &#8220;But generally Rock&#8217;s moods are sunny and his broad shoulders are put to practical and picturesque uses as a woodsman and as a guide.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&nbsp;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Day 2017: Celebrate With LIFE's Most Canadian Photos","description":"In 1953, LIFE Magazine profiled a \"strong man of the north\"","google_news":"canada day, canada, canadian men, paul bunyon, rock put to practical and picturesque uses\"","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4814930\/john-dominis-wild-antelopes\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2rSEIJY","title":"How John Dominis Photographed Wild Antelope Without a Telephoto Lens","friendly_title":"How John Dominis Photographed Wild Antelope Without a Telephoto Lens","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"How John Dominis Photographed Wild Antelope Without a Telephoto Lens","excerpt":"LIFE staff photographer John Dominis, on assignment in Africa in the 1960s, developed an innovative way to capture antelope on the run","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"June 27, 2017","published":"2017-06-27 10:00:26","updated":"2017-06-27 14:00:26","minute":"10:00 am","short":"6\/27"},"authors":[{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4814930\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4814930\/john-dominis-wild-antelopes\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>The photographers on LIFE Magazine&#8217;s staff did it all, taking on assignments wide and varied without a blink of the eye. <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3524708\/photographer-spotlight-john-dominis\/\">John Dominis<\/a> was no exception. He joined LIFE as a staff photographer in 1950 and would go on to shoot some of the biggest stars of the era &mdash; Steve McQueen, <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3619112\/frank-sinatra-portraits-of-the-voice-in-1965\/\">Frank Sinatra<\/a> and Robert Redford to name a few. He also shot one of the <a href=\"http:\/\/100photos.time.com\/photos\/john-dominis-black-power-salute\">most iconic images of the 20th century<\/a>: Tommie Smith and John Carlos giving the black power salute at the Olympics in Mexico.<\/p>\n<p><figure class=\"inline-portrait_small alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=368\" data-attachment-id=\"4815422\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4814930\/john-dominis-wild-antelopes\/01-06-1967-jpg-2\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1831,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;JOHN DOMINIS&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;Cover of LIFE dated 01-06-1967 w. headline \\&quot;The Great Cats of Africa\\&quot; &amp; pic of black leopard; photo by John Dominis.&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;-94262400&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;LIFE MAGAZINE, COPYRIGHT TIME IN&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;01-06-1967.jpg&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}\" data-image-title=\"Great Cats LIFE Magazine Cover 1967\" data-image-description=\"pJan. 6, 1967 cover of LIFE magazine.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=228\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=457\" alt=\"Jan. 6, 1967 cover of LIFE magazine, Great Cats of Africa by John Dominis\" height=\"368\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4815422\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4814930\/john-dominis-wild-antelopes\/01-06-1967-jpg-2\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1831,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"JOHN DOMINIS\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"Cover of LIFE dated 01-06-1967 w. headline \\\"The Great Cats of Africa\\\" & pic of black leopard; photo by John Dominis.\",\"created_timestamp\":\"-94262400\",\"copyright\":\"LIFE MAGAZINE, COPYRIGHT TIME IN\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"01-06-1967.jpg\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"Great Cats LIFE Magazine Cover 1967\" data-image-description=\"pJan. 6, 1967 cover of LIFE magazine.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=228\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?quality=85&w=457\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/dominis-big-cats-africa-cover.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=368\" alt=\"Jan. 6, 1967 cover of LIFE magazine, Great Cats of Africa by John Dominis\" height=\"368\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >John Dominis&mdash;LIFE Magazine<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >Jan. 6, 1967 cover of LIFE magazine. <\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure><br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>On the anniversary of his June 27, 1921, birth, LIFE looks back at one of his lesser known shoots &ndash; the African Antelope, which was a cover story and a follow up to The Great Cats of Africa, which would earn him Magazine Photographer of the year in 1966 and later become a book. In the Editor&#8217;s Note that <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=mFAEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA5&amp;dq=wildebeest&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjag6PxpL7UAhWOZiYKHVIICNcQ6AEINDAD#v=onepage&amp;q=wildebeest&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">accompanies<\/a> the story, Dominis describes how he was able to get the dramatic photo of the &ldquo;bizarre wildebeest&rdquo; (the last slide in the gallery above) without a telephoto lens.<\/p>\n<p>&ldquo;I wanted to get low-angle shots that gave a dramatic sense of their speed. I built boxes out of plywood and mounted cameras inside of them,&#8221; Dominis explained. &#8220;John [Mbuthi, a local whom Dominis worked with on the story] and I worked for three weeks with them. We&rsquo;d go a mile ahead of a herd and put down the boxes and camouflage them. Then we&rsquo;d hide a quarter of a mile away and wait &mdash; maybe for several hours. Meanwhile the light might change and there was no way I could alter the exposure on the cameras. If the animal reached the boxes, I pushed the button that triggered the motorized cameras by a radio signal and ran off a whole roll of film. I must have exposed 40 rolls, but ended up with only one really good frame.&rdquo;<\/p>\n\t\t<form id=\"wpcom-iframe-form-85310f45c02430e52303a86628b00a55-59a93a3815f97\" that John Dominis set up. These rarely seen images show a photographer at work and just how resourceful Dominis was in getting the shot.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-portrait_small alignright \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/life-magazine-cover-antelopes.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=385\" data-attachment-id=\"4814978\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4814930\/john-dominis-wild-antelopes\/5993086-jpg-2\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/life-magazine-cover-antelopes.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1749,2405\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;JOHN DOMINIS&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;Cover of LIFE magazine dated 12-05-1969 w. pic of Roan Antelope (overleaf of cover at # His longtime friend and photo editor M.C. Marden organized the collection, which contains a comprehensive look at his professional and personal work and life. While his archive won&rsquo;t be open to the public until later in 2017, the Briscoe Center &mdash; the photojournalism collection of which also includes the work of Diana Walker, Eddie Adams, Dirck Halstead and others &mdash; is open for research and focuses on a behind-the-scenes look at how Americans experience the world, from politics to war to wildlife, via the media.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;Pictures like [Dominis&rsquo; animal series] have something to say about how Americans (though magazines like LIFE) perceive the outside world,&rdquo; said Ben Wright of the Briscoe Center, in a statement to LIFE. &#8220;These pictures and collections are not only beautiful and interesting: they&rsquo;re historical evidence that help historians to understand the past with That long-running tension was the subject of <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=7E4EAAAAMBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">a 1960 examination by LIFE magazine<\/a> on the 10th anniversary of the war&#8217;s onset, which captured one of the &#8220;endless series of small but meaningful disputes&#8221; along the North-South border in the photographs seen here.<\/p>\n<p>As the article explained, a demilitarized zone (DMZ) of 4,300 yards separated the Communist forces in the North from the U.N. forces in the South, with strict regulations governing what could be allowed inside the buffer area. In this particular instance, U.N. forces had noted &#8220;North Korean troops building a suspicious-looking concrete fortress inside the DMZ&#8221; and, after a meeting was called to discuss the matter, American representatives were asked to figure out what it was. The North Korean forces refused to allow inspection of the structure, going so far as to hold objects in front of the sight-lines of Americans&#8217; binoculars.<\/p>\n<p>After about an hour of &#8220;wrangling,&#8221; the photographer reported, the two sides went their separate ways, adding one more item to the list of &#8220;unresolved issues&#8221; at the border.<\/p>\n<p>Today, nearly seven decades after the DMZ was established, that infamous buffer zone still exists and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/world\/2016\/mar\/21\/north-korea-south-korea-dmz-landmines\" target=\"_blank\">remains<\/a> one of the world&#8217;s <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4766618\/moon-jae-in-the-negotiator\/\">tensest<\/a> borders.<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's
