Dominis\u2014The LIFE Picture Collection\/Getty Images","caption":"Soldiers meeting of Joint Observe team at demarkation line, Korea, 1960.","title":"Korea DMZ 1960","alt":"Korea demilitarizition 1960.","providers":[],"masonry":{"small_width":300,"small_height":200,"large_width":625,"large_height":417}},"titles_outbrain":{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/photography\/life\/","desktop_widget_id":"AR_8","mobile_widget_id":"MB_2","widget_id":"AR_8"},"default_featured_image":{"large":"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/time2014\/img\/featured-images\/TIME-nophoto-624x416.jpg","thumb":"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/time2014\/img\/featured-images\/TIME-nophoto-100x100.jpg"},"seo":{"title":"Korea Border Photos: Scenes From a DMZ Dispute in 1960","description":"LIFE photographer John Dominis captured these moments from a dispute at the DMZ, showing that armistice had not brought peace to Korea.","google_news":"korean war, north korea, south korea, dmz, demilitarized zone, life magazine, 1960, north korea fight, north korea news, north korea photos","keywords":"korean war, north korea, south korea, dmz, demilitarized zone, life magazine, 1960, north korea fight, north korea news, north korea photos","og_title":"Scenes From a Dispute at the Korean Border","og_desc":"Armistice had not brought peace to Korea","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4803406\/anne-frank-diary-anniversary\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2rNvjVa","title":"How Anne Frank&#8217;s Diary Survived","friendly_title":"How Anne Frank\u2019s Diary Survived","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"How Anne Frank&#8217;s Diary Survived","excerpt":"Read an excerpt from LIFE\u2019s new special edition about Anne Frank's life and legacy","format":"article","time":{"pretty":"June 12, 2017","published":"2017-06-12 10:30:16","updated":"2017-06-12 14:30:16","minute":"10:30 am","short":"6\/12"},"modified_time":{"pretty":"June 14, 2017 9:34 AM ET","published":"2017-06-16 09:50:40","updated":"2017-06-16 13:50:40","minute":"10:30 am","short":"6\/14"},"authors":[{"id":373061337,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/life-books-2\/","name":"Daniel S. Levy \/ LIFE Books","bio":"","short_bio":"","types":[],"twitter":"","twitter_url":"","gplus":"","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":null,"contributor":false,"search_link":false,"author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/life-books\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4803406\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4803406\/anne-frank-diary-anniversary\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p><em>It was 75 years ago &mdash; on June 12, 1942 &mdash; that<a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4770800\/anne-frank-secret-annex\/\"> Anne Frank <\/a>received a diary for her 13th birthday. Within a few years, she would have died in a concentration camp, but her diary survived. The following is an excerpt from LIFE&rsquo;s new special edition, <\/em><strong>Anne Frank: The Diary at 70, <\/strong><em>available in the <a href=\"http:\/\/ti.me\/2qphlXX\" target=\"_blank\">TIME Shop<\/a>, on <a href=\"http:\/\/amzn.to\/2qF5vH6\" target=\"_blank\">Amazon<\/a><\/em><em> and at r<\/em><em>etailers everywhere.<\/em><\/p>\n<p>During the years of the Holocaust, the Nazis systematically murdered six million Jews, as well as five million Roma, Sinti, priests, nuns, people with disabilities, homosexuals, and political prisoners. The killing took place throughout Europe in more than 40,000 concentration, labor, prisoner of war, and internment camps, as well as by the <em>Einsatzgruppen, <\/em>mobile killing squads, which machine-gunned entire communities or shoved residents into gas-asphyxiation vans.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Some 80 percent of Dutch Jews died in the Holocaust, giving Holland the highest death rate in western Europe. Of the 107,000 Dutch Jews sent to the camps, only 5,000 lived. The death toll at Auschwitz, where more than a million people died, proved especially high. Of the 60,000 Dutch Jews shipped to Auschwitz, just 673 survived, including 127 men and women who had been on the Frank family&rsquo;s transport there in September of 1944.<\/p>\n<p>Otto Frank was one of them, having been spared because he had been placed in the sick barracks before the Russian army liberated the camp on January 27, 1945.<\/p>\n<p>When the nearly six foot tall Otto left Poland, he weighed less than 115 pounds. He knew that Edith had died, but he was determined to make his way back to Amsterdam. &ldquo;All my hope is the children,&rdquo; he wrote to his mother in Switzerland. &ldquo;I cling to the conviction that they are alive and that we will be together again.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<div class=\"video-container\"><video id=\"brightcove-player-4870846639001\" data-video-id=\"4870846639001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"><\/video><\/div>\n<p>Miep Gies and Bep Voskuijl had kept the firm going during the war. Jo Kleiman, who was released from the Amerfoort concentration camp soon after his arrest because of his health, made it back to the firm too. Yet, as the war drew to an end and the Allies advanced, conditions throughout the Netherlands continued to deteriorate. Distribution of food and supplies was disrupted, and citizens chopped down trees and dismantled homes for fuel. Some resorted to eating tulip bulbs, and more than 20,000 Netherlanders starved to death during what became known as the Hunger Winter. &ldquo;All conversations centered on food,&rdquo; wrote Miep. &ldquo;Food obsessions were affecting all our minds.&rdquo; After Canadian troops liberated Amsterdam in May 1945, displaced residents staggered home. Victor Kugler, who escaped from the Nazis during a forced march, returned to work.<\/p>\n<p>Then on June 3, Otto Frank rang Miep and Jan Gies&rsquo;s doorbell.<\/p>\n<p>Miep would later recall how, after standing speechless for a time, Otto released the &ldquo;thunderbolt&rdquo; of news that Edith would not return but that he held out hope for his daughters.<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/pages.email.time.com\/newsletters\/?newsletter_name=HISTORY&amp;source=article-history\"><em>Get your history fix in one place: sign up for the weekly TIME History newsletter<\/em><\/a><\/p>\n<p>Otto moved in with the Gieses, went back to Opekta, and put ads in papers seeking information on Anne and Margot. Finally, in July, he heard that Jannie Brandes-Brilleslijper might know of their fate. On the 18th of that month, he went to her home.<\/p>\n<p>&ldquo;I could hardly speak because it was very difficult to tell someone that his children were not alive anymore,&rdquo; Jannie recalled. &ldquo;I said, &lsquo;They are no more.&rsquo; He turned deathly pale and slumped down into a chair.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<p>After the Red Cross confirmed their deaths, and Miep knew that Anne would not be coming back for the diary, she told Otto that she had kept it and 327 loose papers safe. Though he was at first too overwhelmed to read the testament his daughter had left of her short life, eventually he girded himself to learn what Anne had written. What he found, he would recall, was &ldquo;so unbelievably exciting&rdquo; that he could barely put it down.<\/p>\n<p>Not only the diary but also the revisions that Anne had made as she dreamed of creating a novel and launching her career had miraculously survived. &ldquo;This brilliant young girl revised her diary because she discovered that she had become a much better writer,&rdquo; the novelist Philip Roth, who conjured up Anne in his novels <em>The Ghost Writer, Exit Ghost, <\/em>and <em>My Life as a Man, <\/em>has observed. &ldquo;The fact that she rewrote it is one sign that, had she survived, she would have achieved an important literary career.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<p>Otto reunited with old friends. Eva Schloss and her mother, Elfriede, survived Auschwitz. One day Otto came by with a small parcel under his arm and carefully took out Anne&rsquo;s diary. &ldquo;It was very emotional,&rdquo; Schloss tells LIFE. &ldquo;He read a few sentences but he always broke into tears.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<p>He had decided that it would be his mission to share Anne&rsquo;s words with the world. Otto had the diary typed up, though he shifted a few entries and omitted sections that were critical of her mother and of Fritz Pfeffer, as well as certain entries that included Anne&rsquo;s musings on her emerging sexuality. It proved difficult to find a publisher until one of Otto&rsquo;s friends showed it to the historian Jan Romein, who wrote a front-page article with the headline &ldquo;<em>Kinderstem<\/em>&rdquo; (&ldquo;A Child&rsquo;s Voice&rdquo;) for the April 3, 1946, edition of the newspaper <em>Het Parool. <\/em>&ldquo;To me, however, this apparently inconsequential diary by a child,&rdquo; Romein wrote, &ldquo;stammered out in a child&rsquo;s voice, embodies all the hideousness of fascism, more so than all the evidence at Nuremberg put together.&rdquo; Soon after, the Amsterdam publisher Contact agreed to publish the book, and on June 25, 1947, it appeared as <em>Het Achterhuis <\/em>(<em>The Secret Annex<\/em>). Otto gave copies to family, friends, the Dutch prime minister, and the royal family. (Miep Gies could not bring herself to read it until the second edition appeared.)<\/p>\n<p>Only two years had passed since the end of the war, but for many the book by the 15-year-old who had written that she still believed that &ldquo;people are truly good at heart&rdquo; already proved useful as a way to personalize the Holocaust. &ldquo;Not only do you have a name and a face and a person in the case of Anne Frank, but you have a very well written diary. It is captivating,&rdquo; Professor Deborah Lipstadt, author of <em>Denying the Holocaust, <\/em>tells LIFE. &ldquo;She is a good writer and she knows how to express herself. She is expressing herself in something she doesn&rsquo;t even know will see the light of day.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-thumbnail alignleft \"><a href=\"http:\/\/ti.me\/2qphlXX\" target=\"_blank\"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" Separated from the rest of her family, she and her sister died of typhoid fever in the concentration camp Bergen-Belsen - As a 12-year old doing her homewo","providers":[],"masonry":{"small_width":300,"small_height":224,"large_width":625,"large_height":467}},"titles_outbrain":{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/photography\/life\/","desktop_widget_id":"AR_8","mobile_widget_id":"MB_2","widget_id":"AR_8"},"default_featured_image":{"large":"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/time2014\/img\/featured-images\/TIME-nophoto-624x416.jpg","thumb":"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/time2014\/img\/featured-images\/TIME-nophoto-100x100.jpg"},"seo":{"title":"Anne Frank Day: How Her Diary Survived to Become a Book","description":"Not only the diary, but also the revisions that Anne had made as she dreamed of launching her career, had miraculously survived the war.","google_news":"anne frank, anne frank diary, anne frank birthday, anne frank day, otto frank, anne frank book, anne frank family, world war ii, nazis, miep gies","keywords":"anne frank, anne frank diary, anne frank birthday, anne frank day, otto frank, anne frank book, anne frank family, world war ii, nazis, miep gies","og_title":"How Anne Frank's Diary Survived","og_desc":"Read an excerpt from LIFE\u2019s new special edition about Anne Frank's life and legacy","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4783803\/paul-schutzer-six-day-war-remembrance\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2qu5WpC","title":"A LIFE Photographer Was Killed on Assignment 50 Years Ago. His Work Endures","friendly_title":"A LIFE Photographer Was Killed on Assignment 50 Years Ago. His Work Endures","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"A LIFE Photographer Was Killed on Assignment 50 Years Ago. His Work Endures","excerpt":"Paul Schutzer died in the earliest hours of the Six-Day War in 1967","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"June 5, 2017","published":"2017-06-05 10:00:19","updated":"2017-06-05 14:00:19","minute":"10:00 am","short":"6\/5"},"authors":[{"id":47730845,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/alice-gabriner\/","name":"Alice Gabriner","bio":"","short_bio":"","types":[],"twitter":"","twitter_url":"","gplus":"","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/11\/alice-gabriner.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":false,"search_link":false,"author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/alice-gabriner\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4783803\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4783803\/paul-schutzer-six-day-war-remembrance\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Fifty years ago &mdash; on June 5, 1967 &mdash; in the first hours of the Arab-Israeli <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3759833\/the-battle-for-jerusalem\/\">Six-Day War<\/a>, LIFE Magazine photographer <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/21616\/paul-schutzer-a-great-photographers-last-pictures\/\">Paul Schutzer<\/a> was killed while riding in a half-track personnel carrier heading toward Gaza.<\/p>\n<figure class=\"image-wrapper no-caption\"><\/figure>\n<p>When he&#8217;d been hired in 1957, Schutzer was the youngest LIFE staff photographer. Over the course of a decade, until his death at age 36, he shot 491 stories for the magazine, including the 1960 Presidential campaign. At the Kennedy inauguration, he captured the iconic photograph of a beaming President with his glamorous wife, <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4581380\/jackie-movie-life-magazine\/\">a symbol of the Camelot mystique.<\/a><br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<p>During the magazine&#8217;s heyday, LIFE&#8217;s picture stories brought readers up close to unfolding events. For a photographer, an assignment was a passport to far-flung worlds and the front lines of history. Behind the scenes, Schutzer recorded the lives of leaders such as Presidents Eisenhower, Nixon and Kennedy, as well as Martin Luther King Jr. Describing her father&rsquo;s work, Schutzer&rsquo;s daughter Dena explains, &ldquo;He focused on the people in power <em>and<\/em> the powerless, the people who were responsible for the events and those who were affected by them.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-custom-size alignleft \"><img data-attachment-id=\"4796462\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4783803\/paul-schutzer-six-day-war-remembrance\/114684518-jpg\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41aa.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1242,1527\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"7.1\",\"credit\":\"PAUL SCHUTZER\",\"camera\":\"NIKON D80\",\"caption\":\"KENNEDY\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1243987200\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"60\",\"iso\":\"400\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.003125\",\"title\":\"114684518.jpg\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"114684518.jpg\" data-image-description=\"<p>KENNEDY<\/p>\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41aa.jpg?quality=85&w=244\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41aa.jpg?quality=85&w=488\" class=\"wp-image-4796462\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/06\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41aa.jpg?w=244&quality=85&w=139\" alt=\"LIFE photographer Paul Schutzer.\" width=\"139\" height=\"171\">\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:139px\"><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>From tensions at the Berlin Wall, to life in the war-torn villages of Vietnam, to the fight for desegregation by men and women demanding basic civil rights, the stories Schutzer covered required him to take numerous risks. Before boarding a bus heading to the Jim Crow south, he once wrote to his wife Bernice, &ldquo;I&rsquo;m going on the bus with the Freedom Riders. The magazine at first ordered me not to go, but the very reasons for not going, is the reason I must&#8230; This story should be told.&rdquo; He was working at a time of American greatness, Bernice now recounts. &ldquo;He wasn&rsquo;t jaded or cynical.&rdquo; He wanted to connect and did so by getting close. He carefully edited his own work after each assignment, telling his wife that he would have been lucky to have taken even ten great photographs in a lifetime.<\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\"> Schutzer traveled extensively through Eastern Europe, where he was deeply affected by what he saw at the site of the Auschwitz concentration camp. His family tells LIFE that, particularly as a Jewish person living and working in the post-war years, he was inspired by the spirit and promise of the new state of Israel. So it was no surprise that, with <a href=\"http:\/\/ti.me\/2qCNRCu\" target=\"_blank\">war looming there in 1967<\/a>, he was eager to be there. Determined, he prevailed on his friend Moshe Dayan, then Israel&#8217;s Minister of Defense, to embed with an assault unit. <\/span><\/p>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">He didn&#8217;t intend to stay long, saying to his wife that he was finished with war. He was shot soon after. &#8220;One perhaps can console oneself that Paul died where he wanted to die and gave his life for what he felt most. And that is true,&#8221; LIFE <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=lVYEAAAAMBAJ&amp;pg=PA3&amp;dq=%22paul+schutzer%22&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiokr6sipjUAhVE5iYKHSvlC-4Q6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&amp;q=%22paul%20schutzer%22&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">eulogized<\/a> the next week. &#8220;But we have lost an exceptional, first-rate man &mdash; in Yiddish this type is called a <em>mensch<\/em>. Paul was a <em>mensch<\/em>.&#8221;<br \/>\n<\/span><\/p>\n<p>After his death, LIFE received many condolences and tributes, including from the master photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson, who said he admired Schutzer&#8217;s work and attitude toward photography. In a telegram, Robert Kennedy wrote, &ldquo;Paul Schutzer was highly regarded as a professional and a friend of President John Kennedy and all those associated with him. His ability, intelligence, sense of humor, and devotion to his craft will be missed by his colleagues and friends.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-custom-size alignleft \"><img src=\"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/plugins\/lazy-load\/images\/1x1.trans.gif\" data-lazy-src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41.jpg?w=199&#038;quality=85&#038;h=146\" data-attachment-id=\"4793698\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4783803\/paul-schutzer-six-day-war-remembrance\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2048,1500\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta=\"{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;4.5&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;Canon PowerShot G12&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;1370124601&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;24.978&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;200&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0.025&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;1&quot;}\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=600\" class=\"wp-image-4793698\" alt width=\"199\" height=\"146\" align=\"none\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4793698\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4783803\/paul-schutzer-six-day-war-remembrance\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41\/\" data-orig-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2048,1500\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"4.5\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"Canon PowerShot G12\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1370124601\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"24.978\",\"iso\":\"200\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.025\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"Paul-Schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41\" data-image-description=\"\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-41.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" class=\"wp-image-4793698\" class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:199px\"><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>Schutzer&rsquo;s complete photographic archive, a unique chronicle of the cold war era, has never been viewed, recognized retrospectively or compiled in a book. His Work Endures"},"email_title":"A%20LIFE%20Photographer%20Was%20Killed%20on%20Assignment%2050%20Years%20Ago.%20His%20Work%20Endures%20%7C%20TIME","email_body":"A%20LIFE%20Photographer%20Was%20Killed%20on%20Assignment%2050%20Years%20Ago.%20His%20Work%20Endures%0A%0APaul%20Schutzer%20died%20in%20the%20earliest%20hours%20of%20the%20Six-Day%20War%20in%201967%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4783803%2Fpaul-schutzer-six-day-war-remembrance%2F%3Fxid%3Demailshare","icon":"gallery","omniture":{"modules":"[time-rail-ad]|[outbrain-video-module]"},"outbrain":{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4783803\/paul-schutzer-six-day-war-remembrance\/","desktop_widget_id":"AR_6","mobile_widget_id":"MB_1","2x2":"AR_9","widget_id":"AR_6","rr_widget_id_1":"SB_2","rr_widget_id_2":"SB_4"},"classes":"metered","article_tile_thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-011.jpg?quality=85&w=74&h=74&crop=1","trending_video_image":{"class":"article_trending_medium","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-011.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","src":{"landscape_large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-011.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-011.jpg?quality=85&w=405&h=229&crop=1","square":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/paul-schutzer-kennedy-six-day-war-011.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1"},"credit":"Paul Schutzer\u2014The LIFE Picture Collection\/Getty Images","caption":"President John F. Kennedy and First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy in the Presidential Box overlooking the crowd at inaugural gala, Jan. 20, 1961.","title":"John F. Kennedy Inauguration","alt":"President John F. Kennedy and First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy in the Presidential Box overlooking the crowd at inaugural gala, Jan. 20, 1961.","providers":[],"masonry":{"small_width":300,"small_height":449,"large_width":625,"large_height":936}},"titles_outbrain":{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/photography\/life\/","desktop_widget_id":"AR_8","mobile_widget_id":"MB_2","widget_id":"AR_8"},"default_featured_image":{"large":"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/time2014\/img\/featured-images\/TIME-nophoto-624x416.jpg","thumb":"https:\/\/s0.wp.com\/wp-content\/themes\/vip\/time2014\/img\/featured-images\/TIME-nophoto-100x100.jpg"},"seo":{"title":"The Six-Day War and the LIFE Photographer Killed in Action","description":"Paul Schutzer died in the earliest hours of the Six-Day War in 1967. Here is a look back at some highlights from his photographic career.","google_news":"paul schutzer, life magazine photographer, photographer killed in action, life magazine, six-day war, israel war, middle east war, 6 day war, guerra seis dias, jfk 1960 election","keywords":"paul schutzer, life magazine photographer, photographer killed in action, life magazine, six-day war, israel war, middle east war, 6 day war, guerra seis dias, jfk 1960 election","og_title":"A LIFE Photographer Was Killed on Assignment 50 Years Ago. His Work Endures","og_desc":"Paul Schutzer died in the earliest hours of the Six-Day War in 1967","canonical_link":""}},{"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/4794147\/parkinsons-disease-life-magazine\/","shortlink":"http:\/\/ti.me\/2qfZQdQ","title":"LIFE Shared This Remarkable Parkinson&#8217;s Disease Story in 1959. A Lot Has Changed Since Then","friendly_title":"LIFE Shared This Remarkable Parkinson\u2019s Disease Story in 1959. A Lot Has Changed Since Then","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"LIFE Shared This Remarkable Parkinson&#8217;s Disease Story in 1959. A Lot Has Changed Since Then","excerpt":"The great photographer Margaret Bourke-White let readers into her private experience with the symptoms","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"June 1, 2017","published":"2017-06-01 16:00:45","updated":"2017-06-01 20:00:45","minute":"4:00 pm","short":"6\/1"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lilyrothman","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lilyrothman","gplus":"115083326003510988963","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_2552.jpg?quality=85&crop=364px%2C105px%2C2338px%2C2337px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Lily+Rothman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/lily-rothman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"},{"id":271801101,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/julia-lull\/","name":"Julia Lull","bio":"","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lullintheaction","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lullintheaction","gplus":"","fb":"","email":"julia.lull@timeinc.com","thumbnail":null,"contributor":false,"search_link":false,"author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/julia-lull\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4794147\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4794147\/parkinsons-disease-life-magazine\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_2\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>The great LIFE photographer <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3735284\/great-lady-with-a-camera-margaret-bourke-white-american-original\/\">Margaret Bourke-White<\/a> was in Tokyo in 1952 when she first discovered that, in the middle of a <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4355162\/margaret-bourke-white-cameras\/\">physically demanding<\/a> photojournalistic career, the dull pain in her left leg was becoming something more. Rising from a meal, she found herself, for a few steps at least, unable to walk.<\/p>\n<p>As she would recount in an <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=nkgEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PP1&amp;pg=PA100#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">extraordinary LIFE story<\/a> seven years later, it turned out &mdash; after years of misdiagnosis and confusion &mdash; that her brief stumble was a symptom of the onset of Parkinson&#8217;s disease, against which she would fight with everything she had <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/vault\/issue\/1971-09-06\/page\/48\/\">for nearly two decades until her death at 67<\/a>. It was, as the introduction to that 1959 article noted, the toughest battle ever faced by a woman who had seen many &mdash; including literal battles in World War II, during which she served as<a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4669481\/margaret-bourke-white-flying-fortress\/\"> the first woman accredited to cover the combat zones <\/a>as a photojournalist.<br \/>\n<div class=\"article-video ad_brightcove_video right-rail-adjacent\"><div id=\"ad_brightcove\" class=\"ad_brightcove_video-wrapper\"><\/div><\/div><\/p>\n<figure class=\"inline-medium alignleft \"><figcaption class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:300px\"><span class=\"credit\" >Alfred Eisenstaedt&mdash;The LIFE Picture Collection\/Getty Images<\/span><span class=\"caption\" >LIFE photographers Alfred Eisenstaedt and Margaret Bourke-White in 1959.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>With photographs by her fellow LIFE photographer <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3491299\/unforgettable-eisenstaedt-22-amazing-photos-by-a-master\/\">Alfred Eisenstaedt<\/a>, some of which are seen above, the story offered up the personal reflections of the woman who had taken the image that appeared on the <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3764198\/lifes-first-ever-cover-story-building-the-fort-peck-dam-1936\/\">first-ever issue <\/a>of the magazine.<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;When I opened some medical insurance papers one day and learned I had Parkinson&#8217;s disease, the name did not frighten me because I did not know what in the world it was,&#8221; she wrote, describing how she learned the name that her doctors had kept from her as they prescribed physical therapy for her unlabeled symptoms. &#8220;Then slowly a memory came back, of a description Edward Steichen once gave at a photographers&#8217; meeting of the illness of Edward Weston, &#8216;dean of photographers,&#8217; who was a Parkinsonian. I remembered the break in Steichen&#8217;s voice: &#8216;A terrible disease&#8230; you can&#8217;t work because you can&#8217;t hold things&#8230; you grow stiffer each year until you are a walking prison&#8230; there is no known cure&#8230;'&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>The knowledge was, unsurprisingly, devastating to Bourke-White.<\/p>\n<p>But she set her mind to learn what she could, to look for anything she could do for relief. She learned, she wrote, that she was just one of three quarters of a million Americans with the disease &mdash; &#8220;often they appear to be struck down at their peak,&#8221; she wrote &mdash; and that, despite this number and the fact that the symptoms had been observed for thousands of years, nobody knew what caused it or how to stop it. Though Bourke-White was an extreme devotee of her exercise routine and even underwent a then-cutting-edge <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=nkgEAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PP1&amp;pg=PA100#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">brain surgery <\/a>to &#8220;deaden permanently&#8221; part of her brain, she knew that the operation she&#8217;d received had only treated some of her disease and that there was no way to know how the symptoms would progress from there.<\/p>\n<p>Today, more than half a century later, as Parkinson&#8217;s researchers and advocates mark 200 years since Dr. James Parkinson <a href=\"https:\/\/archive.org\/details\/essayonshakingpa00parkuoft\" target=\"_blank\">described<\/a> the disease (then known as &#8220;shaking palsy&#8221;) that would come to bear his name, many of the questions that confronted Bourke-White remain frustratingly unresolved for those who receive the same diagnosis she did. Treatment options, however, have advanced significantly since Bourke-White&#8217;s time &mdash; and new advances are offering the hope for something even better.<\/p>\n<div class=\"video-container\"><video id=\"brightcove-player-5456371047001\" data-video-id=\"5456371047001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"><\/video><\/div>\n<p>For one thing, says Dr. Rachel Dolhun, vice president of medical communications at the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson&#8217;s Research, a person with Parkinson&#8217;s disease in the 1950s had no effective options for medication. The most widely prescribed therapy used today &mdash; <a href=\"http:\/\/www.parkinson.org\/understanding-parkinsons\/treatment\/Medications-for-Motor-Symptoms\/Carbidopa-levodopa\" target=\"_blank\">levodopa<\/a>, which temporarily addresses some Parkinson&#8217;s-related loss of dopamine, a movement-regulating brain chemical &mdash; wasn&#8217;t discovered until the late 1960s. It is now also understood in a way that it was not a few decades ago that many different brain chemicals and parts of the body are involved in symptoms linked to Parkinson&#8217;s, not just dopamine and the brain. In addition, the operation that Bourke-White received to basically destroy part of her brain is largely obsolete today, and a patient who was a candidate for brain surgery now would likely instead receive <a href=\"https:\/\/www.michaeljfox.org\/understanding-parkinsons\/living-with-pd\/topic.php?deep-brain-stimulation\" target=\"_blank\">deep brain stimulation<\/a>, which uses wires or electrodes to stimulate parts of the brain. (The physical therapy that was prescribed for Bourke-White, however, is one thing that hasn&#8217;t changed: exercise remains a key way to address symptoms.)<\/p>\n<p>And Dolhun says that advances in genetic science in the last 20 years or so, by offering new insights into how the disease works, have opened up a new range of research angles &mdash; and hope for a real cure, rather than just a better way to address the symptoms. For example, experts are excited by the testing of possible therapies that would target a protein called <a href=\"http:\/\/www.pdf.org\/winter16_asynuclein\" target=\"_blank\">alpha-synuclein<\/a>. &ldquo;Right now, because of those understandings, the development pipeline is richer than it&rsquo;s ever been,&#8221; she says.<\/p>\n<p>Technology is also changing what&#8217;s possible for researchers and scientists. The Michael J. Fox Foundation is running <a href=\"https:\/\/foxinsight.michaeljfox.org\/?utm_source=time-magazine&amp;utm_medium=article&amp;utm_content=rachel-dolhun\" target=\"_blank\">an online clinical study<\/a> in which patients can log on and tell researchers about what it&rsquo;s like to live their experience of Parkinson&#8217;s disease, Dolhun says, and devices like wearables and smartphones are providing new ways to track and communicate about the symptoms. For example, whereas it used to be that a doctor might observe a patient&#8217;s tremor for 15 minutes at a time every couple of months, now an app or a watch can allow patients to log data that gives researchers a 24\/7 look at information about those symptoms.<\/p>\n<p>These new possibilities are particularly important when it comes to Parkinson&#8217;s disease, since the experience of what it&#8217;s like to live with and fight the symptoms is very individualized. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a different journey for every single person who&rsquo;s on it,&#8221; says Dolhun. &#8220;That&rsquo;s why we need the patient experience to inform us so much, and that&rsquo;s why it&rsquo;s so important for patients to be involved directly in research.&rdquo;<\/p>\n<div id=\"action_button_container\"><\/div>\n<p>That&#8217;s also one reason why the openness of people like Margaret Bourke-White mattered in 1959 and continues to matter today. There can still be a stigma attached to telling others that you are experiencing something that might make them see you as weak or in need of assistance. But if those who have it keep their experiences to themselves, it&#8217;s harder for researchers to make progress toward a cure &mdash; and harder for others with the diagnosis to feel that they&#8217;re not alone.<\/p>\n<p>For Bourke-White, as she described for LIFE&#8217;s readers, her fight against Parkinson&#8217;s was, to the fullest extent possible, a reminder to keep working and enjoying what her body could do for every second possible. Nowadays, she wrote in 1959 after the surgery that helped her do that longer than would otherwise have been possible, &#8220;my fingers are more and more often loading my cameras, changing their lenses, and turning their winding buttons as I practice the simple blessed business of living and working again.&#8221;<\/p>\n<p>&#8220;It&rsquo;s not uncommon for people to feel shy about sharing their stories,&#8221; Dolhun says. &#8220;For [Bourke-White] to share her story so publicly I think really speaks volumes. When we see people come forward with their story, it&rsquo;s not an uncommon thing for them to say, &#8216;I really wish I had shared it earlier.&#8217; They feel a burden lifted.&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Bourke-White Parkinson's Disease","slug":"1181706-jpg","caption":"<b>Caption from LIFE.<\/b> \"I reached for his hand quite impulsively, when suddenly it stopped trembling. The balloon's pressure had reached the right spot in the man's brain. His once-rigid fingers were now relaxed, his hand steady for the first time in 10 years. Dr. Cooper asked him to make a fist, then open it. The fingers closed and opened easily. 'God bless you, Dr. Cooper,' the man said. For me this was a magic moment. I knew that in a few days, after the surgeon had deadened the area located by the balloon, this man would be up and about, his tremors relieved. I never met the man, or heard his name, but I shared with him a miracle.\"","credit":"Alfred Eisenstaedt\u2014The LIFE Picture Collection\/Getty Images","alt":"Margaret Bourke-White's struggle with The <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=TrgpwaH8UnYC&amp;pg=PA72&amp;dq=%22children%27s+day%22+moscow+june+1&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiz5K2fyo7UAhWDWSYKHQs3BYgQ6AEINDAD#v=onepage&amp;q=%22children%27s%20day%22%20moscow%20june%201&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">purpose<\/a> of such a day &mdash; some other nations mark it at different times throughout the year and the U.N. has <a href=\"http:\/\/www.un.org\/en\/events\/childrenday\/\" target=\"_blank\">Universal Children&#8217;s Day<\/a> in November &mdash; is to both celebrate the lives of children and remember the importance of protecting them so that they can fulfill the boundless potential that comes with being young.<\/p>\n<p>In honor of that day, LIFE takes a look back through its 37 years of iconic photography to find images that capture the breadth of experience of children around the world. Funny or serious, cute or moving, happy or sad, the kids shown here illustrate in their own ways an element that makes childhood uniquely special. They may be small, but their inner lives, as captured on film by LIFE&rsquo;s expert photographers, are anything but.<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Archives","life":true,"all_sections":["time-section-history","time-section-life"]},"tag":{"name":"photography","slug":"photography","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/tag\/photography\/"},"tags":"Children|international childrens day|LIFE Magazine|photography","hero":{"class":"landscape","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/international-childrens-day-23.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","src":{"small":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/international-childrens-day-23.jpg?quality=85&w=280","small_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/international-childrens-day-23.jpg?quality=85&w=560","landscape_large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/international-childrens-day-23.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/international-childrens-day-23.jpg?quality=85&w=550","large_2x":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/international-childrens-day-23.jpg?quality=85&w=1100","square":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/international-childrens-day-23.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1"},"credit":"Carlo Bavagnoli\u2014The LIFE Images Collection\/Getty Images","caption":"Laughing boy on street in Trastevere, Rome, 1958. Kennedy<\/a>&#8216;s sudden and shocking death in November of 1963, by the bullet of assassin <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4753349\/oswald-kennedy-declassified-documentary\/\">Lee Harvey Oswald<\/a>, TIME chose <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/vault\/issue\/1963-12-06\/page\/35\/\">this letter<\/a> from a reader as the first to print in response to the news:<\/p>\n<blockquote><p>The enormous swell of sympathy and despair that has risen throughout this nation and the world is testimony to these overwhelming aspects of John F. <span class=\"highlight\">Kennedy<\/span> &mdash; he had within him a sense of greatness; he bestowed upon the presidency a literate, a sensitive and even a poetic value. These values were considered by most people to evidence brilliance and genius. It is this that transcends politics and nationality &mdash; the tragedy of his untouched capacities.<\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p>Kennedy was only 46 when he was killed, but he fit a lot of life into those few decades: scholar, writer, war hero, family man, celebrity and &mdash; of course &mdash; politician. And, though a greater number of years have now passed since his death than passed during his life, his legacy continues to be a major touchstone for American culture.<\/p>\n<p>For the 100th anniversary of his May 29, 1917, birth, here&#8217;s a very, very brief look back at his life and the complicated century that he helped shape.<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"History","slug":"history","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/history\/","description":"The news in context, from the archives of TIME. Kennedy Appeared on the Cover of LIFE Magazine","post_type":"post","available":true,"time_article":true,"sub_learn_more_url":"https:\/\/subscription.time.com\/storefront\/subscribe-to-time\/link\/1032487.html","short_title":"See the 20 Times John F. Kennedy Appeared on the Cover of LIFE Magazine","excerpt":"For a decade prior to his death \u2014 and nearly as many years after he was assassinated \u2014 LIFE magazine traced the impact of a young president","format":"gallery","time":{"pretty":"May 26, 2017","published":"2017-05-26 11:00:45","updated":"2017-05-26 15:00:45","minute":"11:00 am","short":"5\/26"},"authors":[{"id":71095586,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/lily-rothman\/","name":"Lily Rothman","bio":"Lily Rothman is History and Archives Editor for TIME.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"lilyrothman","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lilyrothman","gplus":"115083326003510988963","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"http:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/01\/mg_2552.jpg?quality=85&crop=364px%2C105px%2C2338px%2C2337px&resize=100%2C100&strip","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Lily+Rothman","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/lily-rothman\/"},{"id":202304137,"url":"http:\/\/time.com\/author\/liz-ronk\/","name":"Liz Ronk","bio":"Liz Ronk joined TIME in 2012 and is the photo editor for LIFE.com. She holds an MFA in Visual Studies from the Visual Studies Workshop and a BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU in Photography. Along with her work as a photo editor and curator, she is a photographer\/artist with work exhibited and published internationally.","short_bio":"","types":["time staff"],"twitter":"LizabethRonk","twitter_url":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/LizabethRonk","gplus":"101850733335753253710","fb":"","email":"","thumbnail":"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2014\/02\/42dce76357bbf01855e978a2d880c820.jpg?quality=85&w=100&h=100&crop=1","contributor":true,"search_link":"http:\/\/search.time.com\/?site=time&q=Liz+Ronk","author_url":"http:\/\/time.com\/time_author\/liz-ronk\/"}],"has_authors":true,"content":"<aside class=\"right-rail__container right-rail__container--ad\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad__wrapper right-rail__module ad-300-250\"><div class=\"right-rail__ad\" id=\"right-rail__ad-4763638\"><\/div><\/div><br \/>\n<div class=\"OUTBRAIN right-rail__outbrain right-rail__module video-2\" data-src=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4763638\/jfk-covers-life\/\" data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>The first time the then-future president appeared on the cover of LIFE magazine, in 1953, the <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=XkIEAAAAMBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">story<\/a> was as light as could be: &#8220;LIFE Goes Courting With a U.S. Senator.&#8221; Over the course of several pages of photographs, the magazine fawned over the Massachusetts Senator &mdash; the &#8220;handsomest&#8221; man in that legislature, born 100 years ago this Monday on May 29, 1917, so only 36 at the time &mdash; and his 23-year-old fianc&eacute;e Jacqueline Bouvier. &#8220;We hardly ever talk politics,&#8221; Jackie told the magazine, alongside images of the two playing softball and football.<\/p>\n<p>Over the course of the next decade, LIFE followed the young politician as he did much more than court. From his <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=5E0EAAAAMBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">presidential victory in 1960<\/a> to the<a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=XFQEAAAAMBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\"> trials of governing<\/a>, the events of his time demonstrated why LIFE and the JFK went together so well. Part celebrity report and part serious world news, the coverage captured the Kennedy magic.<\/p>\n<p>But only a little more than half of the times that JFK appeared as the featured image or story on the magazine&#8217;s cover during its <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3503080\/the-best-of-life-37-years-in-pictures\/\">37-year-run<\/a> took place during that Kennedy decade. (When his face appeared on additional covers throughout the magazine&#8217;s publication run, it was as an inset or part of collage.) The rest, starting with the <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=U1IEAAAAMBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">Nov. 29, 1963, issue<\/a>, were different. After Kennedy&#8217;s assassination, his legacy endured. He was, as pictured in a 1966 cover that focuses on his brother Robert&#8217;s career, an inescapable figure in the background of the political and cultural history that followed.<\/p>\n<p>On the 100th anniversary of his birth, more than half of that time has passed without JFK&#8217;s presence. And yet, as these images suggest, his influence has suffused a century.<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's Archives","life":true,"all_sections":["time-section-history","time-section-life"]},"tag":{"name":"LIFE Magazine","slug":"life-magazine","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/tag\/life-magazine\/"},"tags":"John F. data-widget-id=\"SB_4\" data-ob-template=\"timemag\"><\/div><\/aside>\n<p>Though summer won&#8217;t official start for a few weeks, <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/3892630\/why-do-we-celebrate-memorial-day\/\">the Memorial Day holiday<\/a> in the U.S. &mdash; celebrated on the <a href=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4346170\/memorial-day-three-day-weekend\/\">final Monday in May<\/a> &mdash; is often considered the unofficial start of the season, which many will celebrate data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/memorial-day-pools.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/memorial-day-pools.jpg?quality=85&amp;w=600\" alt=\"Backyard pool accessories from 1960.\" height=\"221\"><noscript><img data-attachment-id=\"4779171\" data-permalink=\"http:\/\/time.com\/4779099\/vintage-swimming-pool-photos\/00898551-jpg\/\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"JOSEPH SCHERSCHEL\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"Accessories for home pool.\",\"created_timestamp\":\"-299894400\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"00898551.JPG\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"Backyard Pools 1960\" data-image-description=\"pAccessories for home pool.\/p\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/memorial-day-pools.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/memorial-day-pools.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\/\/timedotcom.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/memorial-day-pools.jpg?w=280&#038;quality=85&#038;h=221\" alt=\"Backyard pool accessories from 1960.\" height=\"221\"><\/noscript>\n<figcaption class=\"image-caption\" ><span class=\"credit\" >Joe Scherschel&mdash;The LIFE Picture Collection\/Getty Images<\/span><span class=\"caption\" ><b>Caption from LIFE.<\/b> Equipment roundup shows extras an owner usually buys.<\/span><\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<p>Though the concept of the swimming pool is an ancient one, such places were generally public or semi-public until relatively recently. Even during what swimming-pool expert Jeff Wiltse has <a href=\"http:\/\/www.npr.org\/templates\/story\/story.php?storyId=90213675\" target=\"_blank\">described to NPR<\/a> as the &#8220;pool-building spree&#8221; of the 1920s and &#8217;30s, most of the pools being built were large, resort-style ones. Owning a private pool was so expensive and difficult that only the very wealthy could do so. That changed around 1960 &mdash; due to technology but also, as Wiltse <a href=\"http:\/\/www.npr.org\/templates\/story\/story.php?storyId=90213675\" target=\"_blank\">points<\/a> out, sometimes due to backlash to the desegregation of public pools.<\/p>\n<p>When LIFE magazine sent photographer Joe Scherschel to capture the new world of the backyard swimming pool in 1960, the magazine <a href=\"https:\/\/books.google.com\/books?id=U08EAAAAMBAJ&amp;lpg=PA1&amp;pg=PA64#v=twopage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\">reported that<\/a> U.S. consumers were predicted to spend $250 million &mdash; that&#8217;s more than $2 billion of today&#8217;s dollars &mdash; on private pools. And, thanks to new innovations in pool building, the cost of a backyard pool was way down, so do-it-yourself fans and middle-class families could afford to add a pool to their property for far less than it would have cost before.<\/p>\n<p>But not everything was perfect in the pool, as LIFE pointed out: &#8220;Pool owners must cope with water filters, seasonal changes and sudden friends.&#8221;<\/p>\n","read_more":true,"section":{"name":"LIFE","slug":"life","url":"http:\/\/time.com\/life\/","description":"Classic Pictures From LIFE Magazine's
